The heave of the main\r\nocean on the great sandbank out in the bay, was a heave that made no\r\nsound. The inner sea lay lost and dim, without a breath of wind to stir\r\nit. Patches of nasty ooze floated, yellow-white, on the dead surface of\r\nthe water. Scum and slime shone faintly in certain places, where the\r\nlast of the light still caught them on the two great spits of rock\r\njutting out, north and south, into the sea. It was now the time of the\r\nturn of the tide: and even as I stood there waiting, the broad brown\r\nface of the quicksand began to dimple and quiver\xe2\x80\x94the only moving thing\r\nin all the horrid place.\r\n\r\nI saw the Sergeant start as the shiver of the sand caught his eye.\r\nAfter looking at it for a minute or so, he turned and came back to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA treacherous place, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand no signs of\r\nRosanna Spearman anywhere on the beach, look where you may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took me down lower on the shore, and I saw for myself that his\r\nfootsteps and mine were the only footsteps printed off on the sand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow does the fishing village bear, standing where we are now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nSergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCobb\xe2\x80\x99s Hole,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered (that being the name of the place), \xe2\x80\x9cbears as\r\nnear as may be, due south.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw the girl this evening, walking northward along the shore, from\r\nCobb\xe2\x80\x99s Hole,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cConsequently, she must have been\r\nwalking towards this place. Is Cobb\xe2\x80\x99s Hole on the other side of that\r\npoint of land there? And can we get to it\xe2\x80\x94now it\xe2\x80\x99s low water\xe2\x80\x94by the\r\nbeach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI answered, \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d to both those questions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse my suggesting it, we\xe2\x80\x99ll step out briskly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nSergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to find the place where she left the shore, before it\r\ngets dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe had walked, I should say, a couple of hundred yards towards Cobb\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nHole, when Sergeant Cuff suddenly went down on his knees on the beach,\r\nto all appearance seized with a sudden frenzy for saying his prayers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s something to be said for your marine landscape here, after\r\nall,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cHere are a woman\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps, Mr.\r\nBetteredge! Let us call them Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps, until we find\r\nevidence to the contrary that we can\xe2\x80\x99t resist. Very confused footsteps,\r\nyou will please to observe\xe2\x80\x94purposely confused, I should say. Ah, poor\r\nsoul, she understands the detective virtues of sand as well as I do!\r\nBut hasn\xe2\x80\x99t she been in rather too great a hurry to tread out the marks\r\nthoroughly? I think she has. Here\xe2\x80\x99s one footstep going _from_ Cobb\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nHole; and here is another going back to it. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t that the toe of her\r\nshoe pointing straight to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge? And don\xe2\x80\x99t I see two\r\nheel-marks further down the beach, close at the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge also? I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t want to hurt your feelings, but I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid Rosanna is sly. It\r\nlooks as if she had determined to get to that place you and I have just\r\ncome from, without leaving any marks on the sand to trace her by. Shall\r\nwe say that she walked through the water from this point till she got\r\nto that ledge of rocks behind us, and came back the same way, and then\r\ntook to the beach again where those two heel marks are still left? Yes,\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll say that. It seems to fit in with my notion that she had\r\nsomething under her cloak, when she left the cottage. No! not something\r\nto destroy\xe2\x80\x94for, in that case, where would have been the need of all\r\nthese precautions to prevent my tracing the place at which her walk\r\nended? Something to hide is, I think, the better guess of the two.\r\nPerhaps, if we go on to the cottage, we may find out what that\r\nsomething is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this proposal, my detective-fever suddenly cooled. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t want\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat good can I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe longer I know you, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9cthe more\r\nvirtues I discover. Modesty\xe2\x80\x94oh dear me, how rare modesty is in this\r\nworld! and how much of that rarity you possess! If I go alone to the\r\ncottage, the people\xe2\x80\x99s tongues will be tied at the first question I put\r\nto them. If I go with you, I go introduced by a justly respected\r\nneighbour, and a flow of conversation is the necessary result. It\r\nstrikes me in that light; how does it strike you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot having an answer of the needful smartness as ready as I could have\r\nwished, I tried to gain time by asking him what cottage he wanted to go\r\nto.\r\n\r\nOn the Sergeant describing the place, I recognised it as a cottage\r\ninhabited by a fisherman named Yolland, with his wife and two grown-up\r\nchildren, a son and a daughter. If you will look back, you will find\r\nthat, in first presenting Rosanna Spearman to your notice, I have\r\ndescribed her as occasionally varying her walk to the Shivering Sand,\r\nby a visit to some friends of hers at Cobb\xe2\x80\x99s Hole. Those friends were\r\nthe Yollands\xe2\x80\x94respectable, worthy people, a credit to the neighbourhood.\r\nRosanna\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance with them had begun by means of the daughter,\r\nwho was afflicted with a misshapen foot, and who was known in our parts\r\nby the name of Limping Lucy. The two deformed girls had, I suppose, a\r\nkind of fellow-feeling for each other. Anyway, the Yollands and Rosanna\r\nalways appeared to get on together, at the few chances they had of\r\nmeeting, in a pleasant and friendly manner. The fact of Sergeant Cuff\r\nhaving traced the girl to _their_ cottage, set the matter of my helping\r\nhis inquiries in quite a new light. Rosanna had merely gone where she\r\nwas in the habit of going; and to show that she had been in company\r\nwith the fisherman and his family was as good as to prove that she had\r\nbeen innocently occupied so far, at any rate. It would be doing the\r\ngirl a service, therefore, instead of an injury, if I allowed myself to\r\nbe convinced by Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s logic. I professed myself convinced by\r\nit accordingly.\r\n\r\nWe went on to Cobb\xe2\x80\x99s Hole, seeing the footsteps on the sand, as long as\r\nthe light lasted.\r\n\r\nOn reaching the cottage, the fisherman and his son proved to be out in\r\nthe boat; and Limping Lucy, always weak and weary, was resting on her\r\nbed upstairs. Good Mrs. Yolland received us alone in her kitchen. When\r\nshe heard that Sergeant Cuff was a celebrated character in London, she\r\nclapped a bottle of Dutch gin and a couple of clean pipes on the table,\r\nand stared as if she could never see enough of him.\r\n\r\nI sat quiet in a corner, waiting to hear how the Sergeant would find\r\nhis way to the subject of Rosanna Spearman. His usual roundabout manner\r\nof going to work proved, on this occasion, to be more roundabout than\r\never. How he managed it is more than I could tell at the time, and more\r\nthan I can tell now. But this is certain, he began with the Royal\r\nFamily, the Primitive Methodists, and the price of fish; and he got\r\nfrom that (in his dismal, underground way) to the loss of the\r\nMoonstone, the spitefulness of our first house-maid, and the hard\r\nbehaviour of the women-servants generally towards Rosanna Spearman.\r\nHaving reached his subject in this fashion, he described himself as\r\nmaking his inquiries about the lost Diamond, partly with a view to find\r\nit, and partly for the purpose of clearing Rosanna from the unjust\r\nsuspicions of her enemies in the house. In about a quarter of an hour\r\nfrom the time when we entered the kitchen, good Mrs. Yolland was\r\npersuaded that she was talking to Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s best friend, and was\r\npressing Sergeant Cuff to comfort his stomach and revive his spirits\r\nout of the Dutch bottle.\r\n\r\nBeing firmly persuaded that the Sergeant was wasting his breath to no\r\npurpose on Mrs. Yolland, I sat enjoying the talk between them, much as\r\nI have sat, in my time, enjoying a stage play. The great Cuff showed a\r\nwonderful patience; trying his luck drearily this way and that way, and\r\nfiring shot after shot, as it were, at random, on the chance of hitting\r\nthe mark. Everything to Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s credit, nothing to Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprejudice\xe2\x80\x94that was how it ended, try as he might; with Mrs. Yolland\r\ntalking nineteen to the dozen, and placing the most entire confidence\r\nin him. His last effort was made, when we had looked at our watches,\r\nand had got on our legs previous to taking leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall now wish you good-night, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\r\nshall only say, at parting, that Rosanna Spearman has a sincere\r\nwell-wisher in myself, your obedient servant. But, oh dear me! she will\r\nnever get on in her present place; and my advice to her is\xe2\x80\x94leave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless your heart alive! she is _going_ to leave it!\xe2\x80\x9d cries Mrs.\r\nYolland. (_Nota bene_\xe2\x80\x94I translate Mrs. Yolland out of the Yorkshire\r\nlanguage into the English language. When I tell you that the\r\nall-accomplished Cuff was every now and then puzzled to understand her\r\nuntil I helped him, you will draw your own conclusions as to what\r\n_your_ state of mind would be if I reported her in her native tongue.)\r\n\r\nRosanna Spearman going to leave us! I pricked up my ears at that. It\r\nseemed strange, to say the least of it, that she should have given no\r\nwarning, in the first place, to my lady or to me. A certain doubt came\r\nup in my mind whether Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s last random shot might not have\r\nhit the mark. I began to question whether my share in the proceedings\r\nwas quite as harmless a one as I had thought it. It might be all in the\r\nway of the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s business to mystify an honest woman by wrapping\r\nher round in a network of lies but it was my duty to have remembered,\r\nas a good Protestant, that the father of lies is the Devil\xe2\x80\x94and that\r\nmischief and the Devil are never far apart. Beginning to smell mischief\r\nin the air, I tried to take Sergeant Cuff out. He sat down again\r\ninstantly, and asked for a little drop of comfort out of the Dutch\r\nbottle. Mrs Yolland sat down opposite to him, and gave him his nip. I\r\nwent on to the door, excessively uncomfortable, and said I thought I\r\nmust bid them good-night\xe2\x80\x94and yet I didn\xe2\x80\x99t go.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo she means to leave?\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is she to do when she\r\ndoes leave? Sad, sad! The poor creature has got no friends in the\r\nworld, except you and me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but she has though!\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland. \xe2\x80\x9cShe came in here, as I\r\ntold you, this evening; and, after sitting and talking a little with my\r\ngirl Lucy and me she asked to go upstairs by herself, into Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s the only room in our place where there\xe2\x80\x99s pen and ink. \xe2\x80\x98I want to\r\nwrite a letter to a friend,\xe2\x80\x99 she says \xe2\x80\x98and I can\xe2\x80\x99t do it for the prying\r\nand peeping of the servants up at the house.\xe2\x80\x99 Who the letter was\r\nwritten to I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell you: it must have been a mortal long one,\r\njudging by the time she stopped upstairs over it. I offered her a\r\npostage-stamp when she came down. She hadn\xe2\x80\x99t got the letter in her\r\nhand, and she didn\xe2\x80\x99t accept the stamp. A little close, poor soul (as\r\nyou know), about herself and her doings. But a friend she has got\r\nsomewhere, I can tell you; and to that friend you may depend upon it,\r\nshe will go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Sergeant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as she can.\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland.\r\n\r\nHere I stepped in again from the door. As chief of my lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nestablishment, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t allow this sort of loose talk about a servant\r\nof ours going, or not going, to proceed any longer in my presence,\r\nwithout noticing it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be mistaken about Rosanna Spearman,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she had been\r\ngoing to leave her present situation, she would have mentioned it, in\r\nthe first place, to _me_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMistaken?\xe2\x80\x9d cries Mrs. Yolland. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, only an hour ago she bought some\r\nthings she wanted for travelling\xe2\x80\x94of my own self, Mr. Betteredge, in\r\nthis very room. And that reminds me,\xe2\x80\x9d says the wearisome woman,\r\nsuddenly beginning to feel in her pocket, \xe2\x80\x9cof something I have got it\r\non my mind to say about Rosanna and her money. Are you either of you\r\nlikely to see her when you go back to the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take a message to the poor thing, with the greatest pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nanswered Sergeant Cuff, before I could put in a word edgewise.\r\n\r\nMrs. Yolland produced out of her pocket, a few shillings and sixpences,\r\nand counted them out with a most particular and exasperating\r\ncarefulness in the palm of her hand. She offered the money to the\r\nSergeant, looking mighty loth to part with it all the while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMight I ask you to give this back to Rosanna, with my love and\r\nrespects?\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland. \xe2\x80\x9cShe insisted on paying me for the one or\r\ntwo things she took a fancy to this evening\xe2\x80\x94and money\xe2\x80\x99s welcome enough\r\nin our house, I don\xe2\x80\x99t deny it. Still, I\xe2\x80\x99m not easy in my mind about\r\ntaking the poor thing\xe2\x80\x99s little savings. And to tell you the truth, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think my man would like to hear that I had taken Rosanna\r\nSpearman\xe2\x80\x99s money, when he comes back tomorrow morning from his work.\r\nPlease say she\xe2\x80\x99s heartily welcome to the things she bought of me\xe2\x80\x94as a\r\ngift. And don\xe2\x80\x99t leave the money on the table,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland,\r\nputting it down suddenly before the Sergeant, as if it burnt her\r\nfingers\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good man! For times are hard, and flesh is\r\nweak; and I _might_ feel tempted to put it back in my pocket again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along!\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t wait any longer: I must go back to the\r\nhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll follow you directly,\xe2\x80\x9d says Sergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nFor the second time, I went to the door; and, for the second time, try\r\nas I might, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t cross the threshold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a delicate matter, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d I heard the Sergeant say, \xe2\x80\x9cgiving\r\nmoney back. You charged her cheap for the things, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCheap!\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland. \xe2\x80\x9cCome and judge for yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took up the candle and led the Sergeant to a corner of the kitchen.\r\nFor the life of me, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help following them. Shaken down in the\r\ncorner was a heap of odds and ends (mostly old metal), which the\r\nfisherman had picked up at different times from wrecked ships, and\r\nwhich he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t found a market for yet, to his own mind. Mrs. Yolland\r\ndived into this rubbish, and brought up an old japanned tin case, with\r\na cover to it, and a hasp to hang it up by\xe2\x80\x94the sort of thing they use,\r\non board ship, for keeping their maps and charts, and such-like, from\r\nthe wet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d says she. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen Rosanna came in this evening, she bought the\r\nfellow to that. \xe2\x80\x98It will just do,\xe2\x80\x99 she says, \xe2\x80\x98to put my cuffs and\r\ncollars in, and keep them from being crumpled in my box.\xe2\x80\x99 One and\r\nninepence, Mr. Cuff. As I live by bread, not a halfpenny more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirt cheap!\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, with a heavy sigh.\r\n\r\nHe weighed the case in his hand. I thought I heard a note or two of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Last Rose of Summer\xe2\x80\x9d as he looked at it. There was no doubt now!\r\nHe had made another discovery to the prejudice of Rosanna Spearman, in\r\nthe place of all others where I thought her character was safest, and\r\nall through me! I leave you to imagine what I felt, and how sincerely I\r\nrepented having been the medium of introduction between Mrs. Yolland\r\nand Sergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe really must go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout paying the least attention to me, Mrs. Yolland took another\r\ndive into the rubbish, and came up out of it, this time, with a\r\ndog-chain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWeigh it in your hand, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cWe had three\r\nof these; and Rosanna has taken two of them. \xe2\x80\x98What can you want, my\r\ndear, with a couple of dog\xe2\x80\x99s chains?\xe2\x80\x99 says I. \xe2\x80\x98If I join them together\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99ll do round my box nicely,\xe2\x80\x99 says she. \xe2\x80\x98Rope\xe2\x80\x99s cheapest,\xe2\x80\x99 says I.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Chain\xe2\x80\x99s surest,\xe2\x80\x99 says she. \xe2\x80\x98Who ever heard of a box corded with\r\nchain,\xe2\x80\x99 says I. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mrs. Yolland, don\xe2\x80\x99t make objections!\xe2\x80\x99 says she;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98let me have my chains!\xe2\x80\x99 A strange girl, Mr. Cuff\xe2\x80\x94good as gold, and\r\nkinder than a sister to my Lucy\xe2\x80\x94but always a little strange. There! I\r\nhumoured her. Three and sixpence. On the word of an honest woman, three\r\n_and_ sixpence, Mr. Cuff!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEach?\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth together!\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland. \xe2\x80\x9cThree and sixpence for the two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGiven away, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x9cClean given\r\naway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s the money,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland, getting back sideways to the\r\nlittle heap of silver on the table, as if it drew her in spite of\r\nherself. \xe2\x80\x9cThe tin case and the dog chains were all she bought, and all\r\nshe took away. One and ninepence and three and sixpence\xe2\x80\x94total, five and\r\nthree. With my love and respects\xe2\x80\x94and I can\xe2\x80\x99t find it in my conscience\r\nto take a poor girl\xe2\x80\x99s savings, when she may want them herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t find it in _my_ conscience, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, to give the money back,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsays Sergeant Cuff. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have as good as made her a present of the\r\nthings\xe2\x80\x94you have indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that your sincere opinion, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland brightening up\r\nwonderfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere can\xe2\x80\x99t be a doubt about it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cAsk Mr.\r\nBetteredge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was no use asking _me_. All they got out of _me_ was, \xe2\x80\x9cGood-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBother the money!\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs. Yolland. With these words, she appeared\r\nto lose all command over herself; and, making a sudden snatch at the\r\nheap of silver, put it back, holus-bolus, in her pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cIt upsets\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s temper, it does, to see it lying there, and nobody taking it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncries this unreasonable woman, sitting down with a thump, and looking\r\nat Sergeant Cuff, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s in my pocket again now\xe2\x80\x94get\r\nit out if you can!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time, I not only went to the door, but went fairly out on the road\r\nback. Explain it how you may, I felt as if one or both of them had\r\nmortally offended me. Before I had taken three steps down the village,\r\nI heard the Sergeant behind me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you for your introduction, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nindebted to the fisherman\xe2\x80\x99s wife for an entirely new sensation. Mrs.\r\nYolland has puzzled me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was on the tip of my tongue to have given him a sharp answer, for no\r\nbetter reason than this\xe2\x80\x94that I was out of temper with him, because I\r\nwas out of temper with myself. But when he owned to being puzzled, a\r\ncomforting doubt crossed my mind whether any great harm had been done\r\nafter all. I waited in discreet silence to hear more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, as if he was actually reading my thoughts in\r\nthe dark. \xe2\x80\x9cInstead of putting me on the scent, it may console you to\r\nknow, Mr. Betteredge (with your interest in Rosanna), that you have\r\nbeen the means of throwing me off. What the girl has done, tonight, is\r\nclear enough, of course. She has joined the two chains, and has\r\nfastened them to the hasp in the tin case. She has sunk the case, in\r\nthe water or in the quicksand. She has made the loose end of the chain\r\nfast to some place under the rocks, known only to herself. And she will\r\nleave the case secure at its anchorage till the present proceedings\r\nhave come to an end; after which she can privately pull it up again out\r\nof its hiding-place, at her own leisure and convenience. All perfectly\r\nplain, so far. But,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, with the first tone of\r\nimpatience in his voice that I had heard yet, \xe2\x80\x9cthe mystery is\xe2\x80\x94what the\r\ndevil has she hidden in the tin case?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought to myself, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Moonstone!\xe2\x80\x9d But I only said to Sergeant Cuff,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you guess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not the Diamond,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cThe whole experience of my\r\nlife is at fault, if Rosanna Spearman has got the Diamond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn hearing those words, the infernal detective-fever began, I suppose,\r\nto burn in me again. At any rate, I forgot myself in the interest of\r\nguessing this new riddle. I said rashly, \xe2\x80\x9cThe stained dress!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff stopped short in the dark, and laid his hand on my arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs anything thrown into that quicksand of yours, ever thrown up on the\r\nsurface again?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered. \xe2\x80\x9cLight or heavy whatever goes into the Shivering\r\nSand is sucked down, and seen no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes Rosanna Spearman know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe knows it as well as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat on earth has she got to do but to tie\r\nup a bit of stone in the stained dress and throw it into the quicksand?\r\nThere isn\xe2\x80\x99t the shadow of a reason why she should have hidden it\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nyet she _must_ have hidden it. Query,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, walking on\r\nagain, \xe2\x80\x9cis the paint-stained dress a petticoat or a night-gown? or is\r\nit something else which there is a reason for preserving at any risk?\r\nMr. Betteredge, if nothing occurs to prevent it, I must go to\r\nFrizinghall tomorrow, and discover what she bought in the town, when\r\nshe privately got the materials for making the substitute dress. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nrisk to leave the house, as things are now\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s a worse risk still\r\nto stir another step in this matter in the dark. Excuse my being a\r\nlittle out of temper; I\xe2\x80\x99m degraded in my own estimation\xe2\x80\x94I have let\r\nRosanna Spearman puzzle me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen we got back, the servants were at supper. The first person we saw\r\nin the outer yard was the policeman whom Superintendent Seegrave had\r\nleft at the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s disposal. The Sergeant asked if Rosanna Spearman\r\nhad returned. Yes. When? Nearly an hour since. What had she done? She\r\nhad gone upstairs to take off her bonnet and cloak\xe2\x80\x94and she was now at\r\nsupper quietly with the rest.\r\n\r\nWithout making any remark, Sergeant Cuff walked on, sinking lower and\r\nlower in his own estimation, to the back of the house. Missing the\r\nentrance in the dark, he went on (in spite of my calling to him) till\r\nhe was stopped by a wicket-gate which led into the garden. When I\r\njoined him to bring him back by the right way, I found that he was\r\nlooking up attentively at one particular window, on the bedroom floor,\r\nat the back of the house.\r\n\r\nLooking up, in my turn, I discovered that the object of his\r\ncontemplation was the window of Miss Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s room, and that lights\r\nwere passing backwards and forwards there as if something unusual was\r\ngoing on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t that Miss Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s room?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Sergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nI replied that it was, and invited him to go in with me to supper. The\r\nSergeant remained in his place, and said something about enjoying the\r\nsmell of the garden at night. I left him to his enjoyment. Just as I\r\nwas turning in at the door, I heard \xe2\x80\x9cThe Last Rose of Summer\xe2\x80\x9d at the\r\nwicket-gate. Sergeant Cuff had made another discovery! And my young\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s window was at the bottom of it this time!\r\n\r\nThe latter reflection took me back again to the Sergeant, with a polite\r\nintimation that I could not find it in my heart to leave him by\r\nhimself. \xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand up there?\xe2\x80\x9d I added,\r\npointing to Miss Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s window.\r\n\r\nJudging by his voice, Sergeant Cuff had suddenly risen again to the\r\nright place in his own estimation. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are great people for betting in\r\nYorkshire, are you not?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I was a Yorkshireman,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded the Sergeant, taking my arm, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwould lay you an even sovereign, Mr. Betteredge, that your young lady\r\nhas suddenly resolved to leave the house. If I won on that event, I\r\nshould offer to lay another sovereign, that the idea has occurred to\r\nher within the last hour.\xe2\x80\x9d The first of the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s guesses startled\r\nme. The second mixed itself up somehow in my head with the report we\r\nhad heard from the policeman, that Rosanna Spearman had returned from\r\nthe sands within the last hour. The two together had a curious effect\r\non me as we went in to supper. I shook off Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and,\r\nforgetting my manners, pushed by him through the door to make my own\r\ninquiries for myself.\r\n\r\nSamuel, the footman, was the first person I met in the passage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer ladyship is waiting to see you and Sergeant Cuff,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, before\r\nI could put any questions to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long has she been waiting?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s voice behind me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the last hour, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere it was again! Rosanna had come back; Miss Rachel had taken some\r\nresolution out of the common; and my lady had been waiting to see the\r\nSergeant\xe2\x80\x94all within the last hour! It was not pleasant to find these\r\nvery different persons and things linking themselves together in this\r\nway. I went on upstairs, without looking at Sergeant Cuff, or speaking\r\nto him. My hand took a sudden fit of trembling as I lifted it to knock\r\nat my mistress\xe2\x80\x99s door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the Sergeant over my shoulder,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif a scandal was to burst up in the house tonight. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed! I\r\nhave put the muzzle on worse family difficulties than this, in my\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he said the words I heard my mistress\xe2\x80\x99s voice calling to us to come\r\nin.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\n\r\nWe found my lady with no light in the room but the reading-lamp. The\r\nshade was screwed down so as to overshadow her face. Instead of looking\r\nup at us in her usual straightforward way, she sat close at the table,\r\nand kept her eyes fixed obstinately on an open book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOfficer,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cis it important to the inquiry you are\r\nconducting, to know beforehand if any person now in this house wishes\r\nto leave it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost important, my lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have to tell you, then, that Miss Verinder proposes going to stay\r\nwith her aunt, Mrs. Ablewhite, of Frizinghall. She has arranged to\r\nleave us the first thing tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff looked at me. I made a step forward to speak to my\r\nmistress\xe2\x80\x94and, feeling my heart fail me (if I must own it), took a step\r\nback again, and said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask your ladyship _when_ Miss Verinder informed you that she was\r\ngoing to her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the Sergeant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout an hour since,\xe2\x80\x9d answered my mistress.\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff looked at me once more. They say old people\xe2\x80\x99s hearts are\r\nnot very easily moved. _My_ heart couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have thumped much harder\r\nthan it did now, if I had been five-and-twenty again!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no claim, my lady,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9cto control Miss\r\nVerinder\xe2\x80\x99s actions. All I can ask you to do is to put off her\r\ndeparture, if possible, till later in the day. I must go to Frizinghall\r\nmyself tomorrow morning\xe2\x80\x94and I shall be back by two o\xe2\x80\x99clock, if not\r\nbefore. If Miss Verinder can be kept here till that time, I should wish\r\nto say two words to her\xe2\x80\x94unexpectedly\xe2\x80\x94before she goes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy lady directed me to give the coachman her orders, that the carriage\r\nwas not to come for Miss Rachel until two o\xe2\x80\x99clock. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you more to\r\nsay?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of the Sergeant, when this had been done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly one thing, your ladyship. If Miss Verinder is surprised at this\r\nchange in the arrangements, please not to mention Me as being the cause\r\nof putting off her journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy mistress lifted her head suddenly from her book as if she was going\r\nto say something\xe2\x80\x94checked herself by a great effort\xe2\x80\x94and, looking back\r\nagain at the open page, dismissed us with a sign of her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a wonderful woman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sergeant Cuff, when we were out in the\r\nhall again. \xe2\x80\x9cBut for her self-control, the mystery that puzzles you,\r\nMr. Betteredge, would have been at an end tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt those words, the truth rushed at last into my stupid old head. For\r\nthe moment, I suppose I must have gone clean out of my senses. I seized\r\nthe Sergeant by the collar of his coat, and pinned him against the\r\nwall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamn you!\xe2\x80\x9d I cried out, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s something wrong about Miss Rachel\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nyou have been hiding it from me all this time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff looked up at me\xe2\x80\x94flat against the wall\xe2\x80\x94without stirring a\r\nhand, or moving a muscle of his melancholy face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99ve guessed it at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy hand dropped from his collar, and my head sunk on my breast. Please\r\nto remember, as some excuse for my breaking out as I did, that I had\r\nserved the family for fifty years. Miss Rachel had climbed upon my\r\nknees, and pulled my whiskers, many and many a time when she was a\r\nchild. Miss Rachel, with all her faults, had been, to my mind, the\r\ndearest and prettiest and best young mistress that ever an old servant\r\nwaited on, and loved. I begged Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s pardon, but I am\r\nafraid I did it with watery eyes, and not in a very becoming way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t distress yourself, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant, with more\r\nkindness than I had any right to expect from him. \xe2\x80\x9cIn my line of life\r\nif we were quick at taking offence, we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be worth salt to our\r\nporridge. If it\xe2\x80\x99s any comfort to you, collar me again. You don\xe2\x80\x99t in the\r\nleast know how to do it; but I\xe2\x80\x99ll overlook your awkwardness in\r\nconsideration of your feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe curled up at the corners of his lips, and, in his own dreary way,\r\nseemed to think he had delivered himself of a very good joke.\r\n\r\nI led him into my own little sitting-room, and closed the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me the truth, Sergeant,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you suspect? It\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nkindness to hide it from me now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t suspect,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sergeant Cuff. \xe2\x80\x9cI know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy unlucky temper began to get the better of me again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to tell me, in plain English,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Miss Rachel\r\nhas stolen her own Diamond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Sergeant; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is what I mean to tell you, in so many\r\nwords. Miss Verinder has been in secret possession of the Moonstone\r\nfrom first to last; and she has taken Rosanna Spearman into her\r\nconfidence, because she has calculated on our suspecting Rosanna\r\nSpearman of the theft. There is the whole case in a nutshell. Collar me\r\nagain, Mr. Betteredge. If it\xe2\x80\x99s any vent to your feelings, collar me\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGod help me! my feelings were not to be relieved in that way. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me\r\nyour reasons!\xe2\x80\x9d That was all I could say to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall hear my reasons tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cIf Miss\r\nVerinder refuses to put off her visit to her aunt (which you will find\r\nMiss Verinder will do), I shall be obliged to lay the whole case before\r\nyour mistress tomorrow. And, as I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what may come of it, I\r\nshall request you to be present, and to hear what passes on both sides.\r\nLet the matter rest for tonight. No, Mr. Betteredge, you don\xe2\x80\x99t get a\r\nword more on the subject of the Moonstone out of me. There is your\r\ntable spread for supper. That\xe2\x80\x99s one of the many human infirmities which\r\nI always treat tenderly. If you will ring the bell, I\xe2\x80\x99ll say grace.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For what we are going to receive\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you a good appetite to it, Sergeant,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9c_My_ appetite is\r\ngone. I\xe2\x80\x99ll wait and see you served, and then I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask you to excuse me,\r\nif I go away, and try to get the better of this by myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI saw him served with the best of everything\xe2\x80\x94and I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been\r\nsorry if the best of everything had choked him. The head gardener (Mr.\r\nBegbie) came in at the same time, with his weekly account. The Sergeant\r\ngot on the subject of roses and the merits of grass walks and gravel\r\nwalks immediately. I left the two together, and went out with a heavy\r\nheart. This was the first trouble I remember for many a long year which\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t to be blown off by a whiff of tobacco, and which was even beyond\r\nthe reach of _Robinson Crusoe_.\r\n\r\nBeing restless and miserable, and having no particular room to go to, I\r\ntook a turn on the terrace, and thought it over in peace and quietness\r\nby myself. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t much matter what my thoughts were. I felt\r\nwretchedly old, and worn out, and unfit for my place\xe2\x80\x94and began to\r\nwonder, for the first time in my life, when it would please God to take\r\nme. With all this, I held firm, notwithstanding, to my belief in Miss\r\nRachel. If Sergeant Cuff had been Solomon in all his glory, and had\r\ntold me that my young lady had mixed herself up in a mean and guilty\r\nplot, I should have had but one answer for Solomon, wise as he was,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know her; and I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy meditations were interrupted by Samuel. He brought me a written\r\nmessage from my mistress.\r\n\r\nGoing into the house to get a light to read it by, Samuel remarked that\r\nthere seemed a change coming in the weather. My troubled mind had\r\nprevented me from noticing it before. But, now my attention was roused,\r\nI heard the dogs uneasy, and the wind moaning low. Looking up at the\r\nsky, I saw the rack of clouds getting blacker and blacker, and hurrying\r\nfaster and faster over a watery moon. Wild weather coming\xe2\x80\x94Samuel was\r\nright, wild weather coming.\r\n\r\nThe message from my lady informed me, that the magistrate at\r\nFrizinghall had written to remind her about the three Indians. Early in\r\nthe coming week, the rogues must needs be released, and left free to\r\nfollow their own devices. If we had any more questions to ask them,\r\nthere was no time to lose. Having forgotten to mention this, when she\r\nhad last seen Sergeant Cuff, my mistress now desired me to supply the\r\nomission. The Indians had gone clean out of my head (as they have, no\r\ndoubt, gone clean out of yours). I didn\xe2\x80\x99t see much use in stirring that\r\nsubject again. However, I obeyed my orders on the spot, as a matter of\r\ncourse.\r\n\r\nI found Sergeant Cuff and the gardener, with a bottle of Scotch whisky\r\nbetween them, head over ears in an argument on the growing of roses.\r\nThe Sergeant was so deeply interested that he held up his hand, and\r\nsigned to me not to interrupt the discussion, when I came in. As far as\r\nI could understand it, the question between them was, whether the white\r\nmoss rose did, or did not, require to be budded on the dog-rose to make\r\nit grow well. Mr. Begbie said, Yes; and Sergeant Cuff said, No. They\r\nappealed to me, as hotly as a couple of boys. Knowing nothing whatever\r\nabout the growing of roses, I steered a middle course\xe2\x80\x94just as her\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s judges do, when the scales of justice bother them by hanging\r\neven to a hair. \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d I remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is much to be said on\r\nboth sides.\xe2\x80\x9d In the temporary lull produced by that impartial sentence,\r\nI laid my lady\xe2\x80\x99s written message on the table, under the eyes of\r\nSergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nI had got by this time, as nearly as might be, to hate the Sergeant.\r\nBut truth compels me to acknowledge that, in respect of readiness of\r\nmind, he was a wonderful man.\r\n\r\nIn half a minute after he had read the message, he had looked back into\r\nhis memory for Superintendent Seegrave\xe2\x80\x99s report; had picked out that\r\npart of it in which the Indians were concerned; and was ready with his\r\nanswer. A certain great traveller, who understood the Indians and their\r\nlanguage, had figured in Mr. Seegrave\xe2\x80\x99s report, hadn\xe2\x80\x99t he? Very well.\r\nDid I know the gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s name and address? Very well again. Would I\r\nwrite them on the back of my lady\xe2\x80\x99s message? Much obliged to me.\r\nSergeant Cuff would look that gentleman up, when he went to Frizinghall\r\nin the morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you expect anything to come of it?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked. \xe2\x80\x9cSuperintendent\r\nSeegrave found the Indians as innocent as the babe unborn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuperintendent Seegrave has been proved wrong, up to this time, in all\r\nhis conclusions,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Sergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cIt may be worth while to find\r\nout tomorrow whether Superintendent Seegrave was wrong about the\r\nIndians as well.\xe2\x80\x9d With that he turned to Mr. Begbie, and took up the\r\nargument again exactly at the place where it had left off. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\r\nquestion between us is a question of soils and seasons, and patience\r\nand pains, Mr. Gardener. Now let me put it to you from another point of\r\nview. You take your white moss rose\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy that time, I had closed the door on them, and was out of hearing of\r\nthe rest of the dispute.\r\n\r\nIn the passage, I met Penelope hanging about, and asked what she was\r\nwaiting for.\r\n\r\nShe was waiting for her young lady\xe2\x80\x99s bell, when her young lady chose to\r\ncall her back to go on with the packing for the next day\xe2\x80\x99s journey.\r\nFurther inquiry revealed to me, that Miss Rachel had given it as a\r\nreason for wanting to go to her aunt at Frizinghall, that the house was\r\nunendurable to her, and that she could bear the odious presence of a\r\npoliceman under the same roof with herself no longer. On being\r\ninformed, half an hour since, that her departure would be delayed till\r\ntwo in the afternoon, she had flown into a violent passion. My lady,\r\npresent at the time, had severely rebuked her, and then (having\r\napparently something to say, which was reserved for her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprivate ear) had sent Penelope out of the room. My girl was in\r\nwretchedly low spirits about the changed state of things in the house.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing goes right, father; nothing is like what it used to be. I feel\r\nas if some dreadful misfortune was hanging over us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat was my feeling too. But I put a good face on it, before my\r\ndaughter. Miss Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s bell rang while we were talking. Penelope ran\r\nup the back stairs to go on with the packing. I went by the other way\r\nto the hall, to see what the glass said about the change in the\r\nweather.\r\n\r\nJust as I approached the swing-door leading into the hall from the\r\nservants\xe2\x80\x99 offices, it was violently opened from the other side, and\r\nRosanna Spearman ran by me, with a miserable look of pain in her face,\r\nand one of her hands pressed hard over her heart, as if the pang was in\r\nthat quarter. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, my girl?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, stopping her. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\r\nyou ill?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFor God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, and\r\ntwisted herself out of my hands, and ran on towards the servants\xe2\x80\x99\r\nstaircase. I called to the cook (who was within hearing) to look after\r\nthe poor girl. Two other persons proved to be within hearing, as well\r\nas the cook. Sergeant Cuff darted softly out of my room, and asked what\r\nwas the matter. I answered, \xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Franklin, on the other side,\r\npulled open the swing-door, and beckoning me into the hall, inquired if\r\nI had seen anything of Rosanna Spearman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has just passed me, sir, with a very disturbed face, and in a very\r\nodd manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid I am innocently the cause of that disturbance,\r\nBetteredge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t explain it,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mr. Franklin; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, if the girl _is_\r\nconcerned in the loss of the Diamond, I do really believe she was on\r\nthe point of confessing everything\xe2\x80\x94to me, of all the people in the\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x94not two minutes since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLooking towards the swing-door, as he said those last words, I fancied\r\nI saw it opened a little way from the inner side.\r\n\r\nWas there anybody listening? The door fell to, before I could get to\r\nit. Looking through, the moment after, I thought I saw the tails of\r\nSergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s respectable black coat disappearing round the corner of\r\nthe passage. He knew, as well as I did, that he could expect no more\r\nhelp from me, now that I had discovered the turn which his\r\ninvestigations were really taking. Under those circumstances, it was\r\nquite in his character to help himself, and to do it by the underground\r\nway.\r\n\r\nNot feeling sure that I had really seen the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x94and not desiring\r\nto make needless mischief, where, Heaven knows, there was mischief\r\nenough going on already\xe2\x80\x94I told Mr. Franklin that I thought one of the\r\ndogs had got into the house\xe2\x80\x94and then begged him to describe what had\r\nhappened between Rosanna and himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you passing through the hall, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked. \xe2\x80\x9cDid you meet her\r\naccidentally, when she spoke to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Franklin pointed to the billiard-table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was knocking the balls about,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand trying to get this\r\nmiserable business of the Diamond out of my mind. I happened to look\r\nup\xe2\x80\x94and there stood Rosanna Spearman at the side of me, like a ghost!\r\nHer stealing on me in that way was so strange, that I hardly knew what\r\nto do at first. Seeing a very anxious expression in her face, I asked\r\nher if she wished to speak to me. She answered, \xe2\x80\x98Yes, if I dare.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nKnowing what suspicion attached to her, I could only put one\r\nconstruction on such language as that. I confess it made me\r\nuncomfortable. I had no wish to invite the girl\xe2\x80\x99s confidence. At the\r\nsame time, in the difficulties that now beset us, I could hardly feel\r\njustified in refusing to listen to her, if she was really bent on\r\nspeaking to me. It was an awkward position; and I dare say I got out of\r\nit awkwardly enough. I said to her, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand you. Is\r\nthere anything you want me to do?\xe2\x80\x99 Mind, Betteredge, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t speak\r\nunkindly! The poor girl can\xe2\x80\x99t help being ugly\xe2\x80\x94I felt that, at the time.\r\nThe cue was still in my hand, and I went on knocking the balls about,\r\nto take off the awkwardness of the thing. As it turned out, I only made\r\nmatters worse still. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I mortified her without meaning it! She\r\nsuddenly turned away. \xe2\x80\x98He looks at the billiard balls,\xe2\x80\x99 I heard her\r\nsay. \xe2\x80\x98Anything rather than look at _me!_\xe2\x80\x99 Before I could stop her, she\r\nhad left the hall. I am not quite easy about it, Betteredge. Would you\r\nmind telling Rosanna that I meant no unkindness? I have been a little\r\nhard on her, perhaps, in my own thoughts\xe2\x80\x94I have almost hoped that the\r\nloss of the Diamond might be traced to _her_. Not from any ill-will to\r\nthe poor girl: but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped there, and going back to the\r\nbilliard-table, began to knock the balls about once more.\r\n\r\nAfter what had passed between the Sergeant and me, I knew what it was\r\nthat he had left unspoken as well as he knew it himself.\r\n\r\nNothing but the tracing of the Moonstone to our second housemaid could\r\nnow raise Miss Rachel above the infamous suspicion that rested on her\r\nin the mind of Sergeant Cuff. It was no longer a question of quieting\r\nmy young lady\xe2\x80\x99s nervous excitement; it was a question of proving her\r\ninnocence. If Rosanna had done nothing to compromise herself, the hope\r\nwhich Mr. Franklin confessed to having felt would have been hard enough\r\non her in all conscience. But this was not the case. She had pretended\r\nto be ill, and had gone secretly to Frizinghall. She had been up all\r\nnight, making something or destroying something, in private. And she\r\nhad been at the Shivering Sand, that evening, under circumstances which\r\nwere highly suspicious, to say the least of them. For all these reasons\r\n(sorry as I was for Rosanna) I could not but think that Mr. Franklin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nway of looking at the matter was neither unnatural nor unreasonable, in\r\nMr. Franklin\xe2\x80\x99s position. I said a word to him to that effect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d he said in return. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there is just a chance\xe2\x80\x94a very poor\r\none, certainly\xe2\x80\x94that Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s conduct may admit of some explanation\r\nwhich we don\xe2\x80\x99t see at present. I hate hurting a woman\xe2\x80\x99s feelings,\r\nBetteredge! Tell the poor creature what I told you to tell her. And if\r\nshe wants to speak to me\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t care whether I get into a scrape or\r\nnot\xe2\x80\x94send her to me in the library.\xe2\x80\x9d With those kind words he laid down\r\nthe cue and left me.\r\n\r\nInquiry at the servants\xe2\x80\x99 offices informed me that Rosanna had retired\r\nto her own room. She had declined all offers of assistance with thanks,\r\nand had only asked to be left to rest in quiet. Here, therefore, was an\r\nend of any confession on her part (supposing she really had a\r\nconfession to make) for that night. I reported the result to Mr.\r\nFranklin, who, thereupon, left the library, and went up to bed.\r\n\r\nI was putting the lights out, and making the windows fast, when Samuel\r\ncame in with news of the two guests whom I had left in my room.\r\n\r\nThe argument about the white moss rose had apparently come to an end at\r\nlast. The gardener had gone home, and Sergeant Cuff was nowhere to be\r\nfound in the lower regions of the house.\r\n\r\nI looked into my room. Quite true\xe2\x80\x94nothing was to be discovered there\r\nbut a couple of empty tumblers and a strong smell of hot grog. Had the\r\nSergeant gone of his own accord to the bedchamber that was prepared for\r\nhim? I went upstairs to see.\r\n\r\nAfter reaching the second landing, I thought I heard a sound of quiet\r\nand regular breathing on my left-hand side. My left-hand side led to\r\nthe corridor which communicated with Miss Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s room. I looked in,\r\nand there, coiled up on three chairs placed right across the\r\npassage\xe2\x80\x94there, with a red handkerchief tied round his grizzled head,\r\nand his respectable black coat rolled up for a pillow, lay and slept\r\nSergeant Cuff!\r\n\r\nHe woke, instantly and quietly, like a dog, the moment I approached\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd mind, if you ever take to\r\ngrowing roses, the white moss rose is all the better for _not_ being\r\nbudded on the dog-rose, whatever the gardener may say to the contrary!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing here?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you not in your proper\r\nbed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not in my proper bed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I am one\r\nof the many people in this miserable world who can\xe2\x80\x99t earn their money\r\nhonestly and easily at the same time. There was a coincidence, this\r\nevening, between the period of Rosanna Spearman\xe2\x80\x99s return from the Sands\r\nand the period when Miss Verinder stated her resolution to leave the\r\nhouse. Whatever Rosanna may have hidden, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear to my mind that\r\nyour young lady couldn\xe2\x80\x99t go away until she knew that it _was_ hidden.\r\nThe two must have communicated privately once already tonight. If they\r\ntry to communicate again, when the house is quiet, I want to be in the\r\nway, and stop it. Don\xe2\x80\x99t blame me for upsetting your sleeping\r\narrangements, Mr. Betteredge\xe2\x80\x94blame the Diamond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to God the Diamond had never found its way into this house!\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nbroke out.\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff looked with a rueful face at the three chairs on which he\r\nhad condemned himself to pass the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo do I,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gravely.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\n\r\nNothing happened in the night; and (I am happy to add) no attempt at\r\ncommunication between Miss Rachel and Rosanna rewarded the vigilance of\r\nSergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nI had expected the Sergeant to set off for Frizinghall the first thing\r\nin the morning. He waited about, however, as if he had something else\r\nto do first. I left him to his own devices; and going into the grounds\r\nshortly after, met Mr. Franklin on his favourite walk by the shrubbery\r\nside.\r\n\r\nBefore we had exchanged two words, the Sergeant unexpectedly joined us.\r\nHe made up to Mr. Franklin, who received him, I must own, haughtily\r\nenough. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you anything to say to me?\xe2\x80\x9d was all the return he got for\r\npolitely wishing Mr. Franklin good morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have something to say to you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9con the\r\nsubject of the inquiry I am conducting here. You detected the turn that\r\ninquiry was really taking, yesterday. Naturally enough, in your\r\nposition, you are shocked and distressed. Naturally enough, also, you\r\nvisit your own angry sense of your own family scandal upon Me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Franklin broke in, sharply enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to remind you, sir, that I have at any rate, thus far, not been\r\n_proved_ to be wrong. Bearing that in mind, be pleased to remember, at\r\nthe same time, that I am an officer of the law acting here under the\r\nsanction of the mistress of the house. Under these circumstances, is\r\nit, or is it not, your duty as a good citizen, to assist me with any\r\nspecial information which you may happen to possess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI possess no special information,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mr. Franklin.\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff put that answer by him, as if no answer had been made.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may save my time, sir, from being wasted on an inquiry at a\r\ndistance,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cif you choose to understand me and speak out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand you,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Franklin; \xe2\x80\x9cand I have nothing to\r\nsay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the female servants (I won\xe2\x80\x99t mention names) spoke to you\r\nprivately, sir, last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOnce more Mr. Franklin cut him short; once more Mr. Franklin answered,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have nothing to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStanding by in silence, I thought of the movement in the swing-door on\r\nthe previous evening, and of the coat-tails which I had seen\r\ndisappearing down the passage. Sergeant Cuff had, no doubt, just heard\r\nenough, before I interrupted him, to make him suspect that Rosanna had\r\nrelieved her mind by confessing something to Mr. Franklin Blake.\r\n\r\nThis notion had barely struck me\xe2\x80\x94when who should appear at the end of\r\nthe shrubbery walk but Rosanna Spearman in her own proper person! She\r\nwas followed by Penelope, who was evidently trying to make her retrace\r\nher steps to the house. Seeing that Mr. Franklin was not alone, Rosanna\r\ncame to a standstill, evidently in great perplexity what to do next.\r\nPenelope waited behind her. Mr. Franklin saw the girls as soon as I saw\r\nthem. The Sergeant, with his devilish cunning, took on not to have\r\nnoticed them at all. All this happened in an instant. Before either Mr.\r\nFranklin or I could say a word, Sergeant Cuff struck in smoothly, with\r\nan appearance of continuing the previous conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou needn\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid of harming the girl, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Mr.\r\nFranklin, speaking in a loud voice, so that Rosanna might hear him. \xe2\x80\x9cOn\r\nthe contrary, I recommend you to honour me with your confidence, if you\r\nfeel any interest in Rosanna Spearman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Franklin instantly took on not to have noticed the girls either. He\r\nanswered, speaking loudly on his side:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take no interest whatever in Rosanna Spearman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI looked towards the end of the walk. All I saw at the distance was\r\nthat Rosanna suddenly turned round, the moment Mr. Franklin had spoken.\r\nInstead of resisting Penelope, as she had done the moment before, she\r\nnow let my daughter take her by the arm and lead her back to the house.\r\n\r\nThe breakfast-bell rang as the two girls disappeared\xe2\x80\x94and even Sergeant\r\nCuff was now obliged to give it up as a bad job! He said to me quietly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall go to Frizinghall, Mr. Betteredge; and I shall be back before\r\ntwo.\xe2\x80\x9d He went his way without a word more\xe2\x80\x94and for some few hours we\r\nwere well rid of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must make it right with Rosanna,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Franklin said to me, when we\r\nwere alone. \xe2\x80\x9cI seem to be fated to say or do something awkward, before\r\nthat unlucky girl. You must have seen yourself that Sergeant Cuff laid\r\na trap for both of us. If he could confuse _me_, or irritate _her_ into\r\nbreaking out, either she or I might have said something which would\r\nanswer his purpose. On the spur of the moment, I saw no better way out\r\nof it than the way I took. It stopped the girl from saying anything,\r\nand it showed the Sergeant that I saw through him. He was evidently\r\nlistening, Betteredge, when I was speaking to you last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had done worse than listen, as I privately thought to myself. He had\r\nremembered my telling him that the girl was in love with Mr. Franklin;\r\nand he had calculated on _that_, when he appealed to Mr. Franklin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninterest in Rosanna\xe2\x80\x94in Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s hearing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to listening, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I remarked (keeping the other point to myself),\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwe shall all be rowing in the same boat if this sort of thing goes on\r\nmuch longer. Prying, and peeping, and listening are the natural\r\noccupations of people situated as we are. In another day or two, Mr.\r\nFranklin, we shall all be struck dumb together\xe2\x80\x94for this reason, that we\r\nshall all be listening to surprise each other\xe2\x80\x99s secrets, and all know\r\nit. Excuse my breaking out, sir. The horrid mystery hanging over us in\r\nthis house gets into my head like liquor, and makes me wild. I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nforget what you have told me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take the first opportunity of making\r\nit right with Rosanna Spearman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t said anything to her yet about last night, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nFranklin asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen say nothing now. I had better not invite the girl\xe2\x80\x99s confidence,\r\nwith the Sergeant on the look-out to surprise us together. My conduct\r\nis not very consistent, Betteredge\xe2\x80\x94is it? I see no way out of this\r\nbusiness, which isn\xe2\x80\x99t dreadful to think of, unless the Diamond is\r\ntraced to Rosanna. And yet I can\xe2\x80\x99t, and won\xe2\x80\x99t, help Sergeant Cuff to\r\nfind the girl out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnreasonable enough, no doubt. But it was my state of mind as well. I\r\nthoroughly understood him. If you will, for once in your life, remember\r\nthat you are mortal, perhaps you will thoroughly understand him too.\r\n\r\nThe state of things, indoors and out, while Sergeant Cuff was on his\r\nway to Frizinghall, was briefly this:\r\n\r\nMiss Rachel waited for the time when the carriage was to take her to\r\nher aunt\xe2\x80\x99s, still obstinately shut up in her own room. My lady and Mr.\r\nFranklin breakfasted together. After breakfast, Mr. Franklin took one\r\nof his sudden resolutions, and went out precipitately to quiet his mind\r\nby a long walk. I was the only person who saw him go; and he told me he\r\nshould be back before the Sergeant returned. The change in the weather,\r\nforeshadowed overnight, had come. Heavy rain had been followed soon\r\nafter dawn, by high wind. It was blowing fresh, as the day got on. But\r\nthough the clouds threatened more than once, the rain still held off.\r\nIt was not a bad day for a walk, if you were young and strong, and\r\ncould breast the great gusts of wind which came sweeping in from the\r\nsea.\r\n\r\nI attended my lady after breakfast, and assisted her in the settlement\r\nof our household accounts. She only once alluded to the matter of the\r\nMoonstone, and that was in the way of forbidding any present mention of\r\nit between us. \xe2\x80\x9cWait till that man comes back,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, meaning the\r\nSergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cWe _must_ speak of it then: we are not obliged to speak of\r\nit now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter leaving my mistress, I found Penelope waiting for me in my room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish, father, you would come and speak to Rosanna,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nvery uneasy about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI suspected what was the matter readily enough. But it is a maxim of\r\nmine that men (being superior creatures) are bound to improve women\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nthey can. When a woman wants me to do anything (my daughter, or not, it\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter), I always insist on knowing why. The oftener you make\r\nthem rummage their own minds for a reason, the more manageable you will\r\nfind them in all the relations of life. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t their fault (poor\r\nwretches!) that they act first and think afterwards; it\xe2\x80\x99s the fault of\r\nthe fools who humour them.\r\n\r\nPenelope\xe2\x80\x99s reason why, on this occasion, may be given in her own words.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid, father,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Franklin has hurt Rosanna\r\ncruelly, without intending it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat took Rosanna into the shrubbery walk?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer own madness,\xe2\x80\x9d says Penelope; \xe2\x80\x9cI can call it nothing else. She was\r\nbent on speaking to Mr. Franklin, this morning, come what might of it.\r\nI did my best to stop her; you saw that. If I could only have got her\r\naway before she heard those dreadful words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! there!\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t lose your head. I can\xe2\x80\x99t call to mind\r\nthat anything happened to alarm Rosanna.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to alarm her, father. But Mr. Franklin said he took no\r\ninterest whatever in her\xe2\x80\x94and, oh, he said it in such a cruel voice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said it to stop the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s mouth,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told her that,\xe2\x80\x9d says Penelope. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you see, father (though Mr.\r\nFranklin isn\xe2\x80\x99t to blame), he\xe2\x80\x99s been mortifying and disappointing her\r\nfor weeks and weeks past; and now this comes on the top of it all! She\r\nhas no right, of course, to expect him to take any interest in her.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite monstrous that she should forget herself and her station in\r\nthat way. But she seems to have lost pride, and proper feeling, and\r\neverything. She frightened me, father, when Mr. Franklin said those\r\nwords. They seemed to turn her into stone. A sudden quiet came over\r\nher, and she has gone about her work, ever since, like a woman in a\r\ndream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI began to feel a little uneasy. There was something in the way\r\nPenelope put it which silenced my superior sense. I called to mind, now\r\nmy thoughts were directed that way, what had passed between Mr.\r\nFranklin and Rosanna overnight. She looked cut to the heart on that\r\noccasion; and now, as ill-luck would have it, she had been unavoidably\r\nstung again, poor soul, on the tender place. Sad! sad!\xe2\x80\x94all the more sad\r\nbecause the girl had no reason to justify her, and no right to feel it.\r\n\r\nI had promised Mr. Franklin to speak to Rosanna, and this seemed the\r\nfittest time for keeping my word.\r\n\r\nWe found the girl sweeping the corridor outside the bedrooms, pale and\r\ncomposed, and neat as ever in her modest print dress. I noticed a\r\ncurious dimness and dullness in her eyes\xe2\x80\x94not as if she had been crying\r\nbut as if she had been looking at something too long. Possibly, it was\r\na misty something raised by her own thoughts. There was certainly no\r\nobject about her to look at which she had not seen already hundreds on\r\nhundreds of times.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCheer up, Rosanna!\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t fret over your own fancies. I\r\nhave got something to say to you from Mr. Franklin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thereupon put the matter in the right view before her, in the\r\nfriendliest and most comforting words I could find. My principles, in\r\nregard to the other sex, are, as you may have noticed, very severe. But\r\nsomehow or other, when I come face to face with the women, my practice\r\n(I own) is not conformable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Franklin is very kind and considerate. Please to thank him.\xe2\x80\x9d That\r\nwas all the answer she made me.\r\n\r\nMy daughter had already noticed that Rosanna went about her work like a\r\nwoman in a dream. I now added to this observation, that she also\r\nlistened and spoke like a woman in a dream. I doubted if her mind was\r\nin a fit condition to take in what I had said to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure, Rosanna, that you understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe echoed me, not like a living woman, but like a creature moved by\r\nmachinery. She went on sweeping all the time. I took away the broom as\r\ngently and as kindly as I could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, my girl!\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is not like yourself. You have got\r\nsomething on your mind. I\xe2\x80\x99m your friend\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99ll stand your friend,\r\neven if you have done wrong. Make a clean breast of it, Rosanna\xe2\x80\x94make a\r\nclean breast of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe time had been, when my speaking to her in that way would have\r\nbrought the tears into her eyes. I could see no change in them now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll make a clean breast of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo my lady?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Mr. Franklin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; to Mr. Franklin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI hardly knew what to say to that. She was in no condition to\r\nunderstand the caution against speaking to him in private, which Mr.\r\nFranklin had directed me to give her. Feeling my way, little by little,\r\nI only told her Mr. Franklin had gone out for a walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI shan\xe2\x80\x99t trouble Mr. Franklin,\r\ntoday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not speak to my lady?\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe way to relieve your mind is to\r\nspeak to the merciful and Christian mistress who has always been kind\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at me for a moment with a grave and steady attention, as if\r\nshe was fixing what I said in her mind. Then she took the broom out of\r\nmy hands and moved off with it slowly, a little way down the corridor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, going on with her sweeping, and speaking to herself; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow a better way of relieving my mind than that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease to let me go on with my work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPenelope followed her, and offered to help her.\r\n\r\nShe answered, \xe2\x80\x9cNo. I want to do my work. Thank you, Penelope.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nlooked round at me. \xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Mr. Betteredge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was no moving her\xe2\x80\x94there was nothing more to be said. I signed to\r\nPenelope to come away with me. We left her, as we had found her,\r\nsweeping the corridor, like a woman in a dream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a matter for the doctor to look into,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s beyond\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy daughter reminded me of Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s illness, owing (as you may\r\nremember) to the chill he had caught on the night of the dinner-party.\r\nHis assistant\xe2\x80\x94a certain Mr. Ezra Jennings\xe2\x80\x94was at our disposal, to be\r\nsure. But nobody knew much about him in our parts. He had been engaged\r\nby Mr. Candy under rather peculiar circumstances; and, right or wrong,\r\nwe none of us liked him or trusted him. There were other doctors at\r\nFrizinghall. But they were strangers to our house; and Penelope\r\ndoubted, in Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s present state, whether strangers might not do her\r\nmore harm than good.\r\n\r\nI thought of speaking to my lady. But, remembering the heavy weight of\r\nanxiety which she already had on her mind, I hesitated to add to all\r\nthe other vexations this new trouble. Still, there was a necessity for\r\ndoing something. The girl\xe2\x80\x99s state was, to my thinking, downright\r\nalarming\xe2\x80\x94and my mistress ought to be informed of it. Unwilling enough,\r\nI went to her sitting-room. No one was there. My lady was shut up with\r\nMiss Rachel. It was impossible for me to see her till she came out\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nI waited in vain till the clock on the front staircase struck the\r\nquarter to two. Five minutes afterwards, I heard my name called, from\r\nthe drive outside the house. I knew the voice directly. Sergeant Cuff\r\nhad returned from Frizinghall.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII\r\n\r\nGoing down to the front door, I met the Sergeant on the steps.\r\n\r\nIt went against the grain with me, after what had passed between us, to\r\nshow him that I felt any sort of interest in his proceedings. In spite\r\nof myself, however, I felt an interest that there was no resisting. My\r\nsense of dignity sank from under me, and out came the words: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat news\r\nfrom Frizinghall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have seen the Indians,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sergeant Cuff. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have found\r\nout what Rosanna bought privately in the town, on Thursday last. The\r\nIndians will be set free on Wednesday in next week. There isn\xe2\x80\x99t a doubt\r\non my mind, and there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a doubt on Mr. Murthwaite\xe2\x80\x99s mind, that they\r\ncame to this place to steal the Moonstone. Their calculations were all\r\nthrown out, of course, by what happened in the house on Wednesday\r\nnight; and they have no more to do with the actual loss of the jewel\r\nthan you have. But I can tell you one thing, Mr. Betteredge\xe2\x80\x94if _we_\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t find the Moonstone, _they_ will. You have not heard the last of\r\nthe three jugglers yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Franklin came back from his walk as the Sergeant said those\r\nstartling words. Governing his curiosity better than I had governed\r\nmine, he passed us without a word, and went on into the house.\r\n\r\nAs for me, having already dropped my dignity, I determined to have the\r\nwhole benefit of the sacrifice. \xe2\x80\x9cSo much for the Indians,\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat about Rosanna next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mystery in that quarter is thicker than ever,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\ntraced her to a shop at Frizinghall, kept by a linen draper named\r\nMaltby. She bought nothing whatever at any of the other drapers\xe2\x80\x99 shops,\r\nor at any milliners\xe2\x80\x99 or tailors\xe2\x80\x99 shops; and she bought nothing at\r\nMaltby\xe2\x80\x99s but a piece of long cloth. She was very particular in choosing\r\na certain quality. As to quantity, she bought enough to make a\r\nnightgown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose nightgown?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer own, to be sure. Between twelve and three, on the Thursday\r\nmorning, she must have slipped down to your young lady\xe2\x80\x99s room, to\r\nsettle the hiding of the Moonstone while all the rest of you were in\r\nbed. In going back to her own room, her nightgown must have brushed the\r\nwet paint on the door. She couldn\xe2\x80\x99t wash out the stain; and she\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t safely destroy the night-gown without first providing another\r\nlike it, to make the inventory of her linen complete.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat proves that it was Rosanna\xe2\x80\x99s nightgown?\xe2\x80\x9d I objected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe material she bought for making the substitute dress,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nSergeant. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it had been Miss Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s nightgown, she would have had\r\nto buy lace, and frilling, and Lord knows what besides; and she\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have had time to make it in one night. Plain long cloth means\r\na plain servant\xe2\x80\x99s nightgown. No, no, Mr. Betteredge\xe2\x80\x94all that is clear\r\nenough. The pinch of the question is\xe2\x80\x94why, after having provided the\r\nsubstitute dress, does she hide the smeared nightgown, instead of\r\ndestroying it? If the girl won\xe2\x80\x99t speak out, there is only one way of\r\nsettling the difficulty. The hiding-place at the Shivering Sand must be\r\nsearched\xe2\x80\x94and the true state of the case will be discovered there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you to find the place?\xe2\x80\x9d I inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to disappoint you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut that\xe2\x80\x99s a secret\r\nwhich I mean to keep to myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n(Not to irritate your curiosity, as he irritated mine, I may here\r\ninform you that he had come back from Frizinghall provided with a\r\nsearch-warrant. His experience in such matters told him that Rosanna\r\nwas in all probability carrying about her a memorandum of the\r\nhiding-place, to guide her, in case she returned to it, under changed\r\ncircumstances and after a lapse of time. Possessed of this memorandum,\r\nthe Sergeant would be furnished with all that he could desire.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Mr. Betteredge,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9csuppose we drop speculation, and\r\nget to business. I told Joyce to have an eye on Rosanna. Where is\r\nJoyce?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJoyce was the Frizinghall policeman, who had been left by\r\nSuperintendent Seegrave at Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s disposal. The clock struck\r\ntwo, as he put the question; and, punctual to the moment, the carriage\r\ncame round to take Miss Rachel to her aunt\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne thing at a time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Sergeant, stopping me as I was about to\r\nsend in search of Joyce. \xe2\x80\x9cI must attend to Miss Verinder first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the rain was still threatening, it was the close carriage that had\r\nbeen appointed to take Miss Rachel to Frizinghall. Sergeant Cuff\r\nbeckoned Samuel to come down to him from the rumble behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will see a friend of mine waiting among the trees, on this side of\r\nthe lodge gate,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMy friend, without stopping the carriage,\r\nwill get up into the rumble with you. You have nothing to do but to\r\nhold your tongue, and shut your eyes. Otherwise, you will get into\r\ntrouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that advice, he sent the footman back to his place. What Samuel\r\nthought I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. It was plain, to my mind, that Miss Rachel was to\r\nbe privately kept in view from the time when she left our house\xe2\x80\x94if she\r\ndid leave it. A watch set on my young lady! A spy behind her in the\r\nrumble of her mother\xe2\x80\x99s carriage! I could have cut my own tongue out for\r\nhaving forgotten myself so far as to speak to Sergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nThe first person to come out of the house was my lady. She stood aside,\r\non the top step, posting herself there to see what happened. Not a word\r\ndid she say, either to the Sergeant or to me. With her lips closed, and\r\nher arms folded in the light garden cloak which she had wrapped round\r\nher on coming into the air, there she stood, as still as a statue,\r\nwaiting for her daughter to appear.\r\n\r\nIn a minute more, Miss Rachel came downstairs\xe2\x80\x94very nicely dressed in\r\nsome soft yellow stuff, that set off her dark complexion, and clipped\r\nher tight (in the form of a jacket) round the waist. She had a smart\r\nlittle straw hat on her head, with a white veil twisted round it. She\r\nhad primrose-coloured gloves that fitted her hands like a second skin.\r\nHer beautiful black hair looked as smooth as satin under her hat. Her\r\nlittle ears were like rosy shells\xe2\x80\x94they had a pearl dangling from each\r\nof them. She came swiftly out to us, as straight as a lily on its stem,\r\nand as lithe and supple in every movement she made as a young cat.\r\nNothing that I could discover was altered in her pretty face, but her\r\neyes and her lips. Her eyes were brighter and fiercer than I liked to\r\nsee; and her lips had so completely lost their colour and their smile\r\nthat I hardly knew them again. She kissed her mother in a hasty and\r\nsudden manner on the cheek. She said, \xe2\x80\x9cTry to forgive me, mamma\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthen pulled down her veil over her face so vehemently that she tore it.\r\nIn another moment she had run down the steps, and had rushed into the\r\ncarriage as if it was a hiding-place.\r\n\r\nSergeant Cuff was just as quick on his side. He put Samuel back, and\r\nstood before Miss Rachel, with the open carriage-door in his hand, at\r\nthe instant when she settled herself in her place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d says Miss Rachel, from behind her veil.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to say one word to you, miss,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Sergeant, \xe2\x80\x9cbefore\r\nyou go. I can\xe2\x80\x99t presume to stop your paying a visit to your aunt. I can\r\nonly venture to say that your leaving us, as things are now, puts an\r\nobstacle in the way of my recovering your Diamond. Please to understand\r\nthat; and now decide for yourself whether you go or stay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Rachel never even answered him. \xe2\x80\x9cDrive on, James!\xe2\x80\x9d she called out\r\nto the coachman.\r\n\r\nWithout another word, the Sergeant shut the carriage-door. Just as he\r\nclosed it, Mr. Franklin came running down the steps. \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\r\nRachel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, holding out his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrive on!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Miss Rachel, louder than ever, and taking no more\r\nnotice of Mr. Franklin than she had taken of Sergeant Cuff.\r\n\r\nMr. Franklin stepped back thunderstruck, as well he might be. The\r\ncoachman, not knowing what to do, looked towards my lady, still\r\nstanding immovable on the top step. My lady, with anger and sorrow and\r\nshame all struggling together in her face, made him a sign to start the\r\nhorses, and then turned back hastily into the house.
