It was only after pausing a\r\nlittle first that I was able to go on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you any light in your room?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone\xe2\x80\x94until I got up again, and lit my candle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long was that, after you had gone to bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout an hour after, I think. About one o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you leave your bedroom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was going to leave it. I had put on my dressing-gown; and I was\r\ngoing into my sitting-room to get a book\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you opened your bedroom door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had just opened it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you had not gone into the sitting-room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94I was stopped from going into it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat stopped you?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw a light, under the door; and I heard footsteps approaching it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you frightened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot then. I knew my poor mother was a bad sleeper; and I remembered\r\nthat she had tried hard, that evening, to persuade me to let her take\r\ncharge of my Diamond. She was unreasonably anxious about it, as I\r\nthought; and I fancied she was coming to me to see if I was in bed, and\r\nto speak to me about the Diamond again, if she found that I was up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI blew out my candle, so that she might think I was in bed. I was\r\nunreasonable, on my side\xe2\x80\x94I was determined to keep my Diamond in the\r\nplace of my own choosing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter blowing out the candle, did you go back to bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had no time to go back. At the moment when I blew the candle out,\r\nthe sitting-room door opened, and I saw\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou saw?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDressed as usual?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my nightgown?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn your nightgown\xe2\x80\x94with your bedroom candle in your hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you see my face?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlainly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite plainly. The candle in your hand showed it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere my eyes open?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you notice anything strange in them? Anything like a fixed, vacant\r\nexpression?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the sort. Your eyes were bright\xe2\x80\x94brighter than usual. You\r\nlooked about in the room, as if you knew you were where you ought not\r\nto be, and as if you were afraid of being found out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you observe one thing when I came into the room\xe2\x80\x94did you observe\r\nhow I walked?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou walked as you always do. You came in as far as the middle of the\r\nroom\xe2\x80\x94and then you stopped and looked about you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you do, on first seeing me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could do nothing. I was petrified. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t call\r\nout, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even move to shut my door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould I see you, where you stood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might certainly have seen me. But you never looked towards me.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s useless to ask the question. I am sure you never saw me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you sure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you have taken the Diamond? would you have acted as you did\r\nafterwards? would you be here now\xe2\x80\x94if you had seen that I was awake and\r\nlooking at you? Don\xe2\x80\x99t make me talk of that part of it! I want to answer\r\nyou quietly. Help me to keep as calm as I can. Go on to something\r\nelse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was right\xe2\x80\x94in every way, right. I went on to other things.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I do, after I had got to the middle of the room, and had\r\nstopped there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou turned away, and went straight to the corner near the window\xe2\x80\x94where\r\nmy Indian cabinet stands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was at the cabinet, my back must have been turned towards you.\r\nHow did you see what I was doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you moved, I moved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo as to see what I was about with my hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are three glasses in my sitting-room. As you stood there, I saw\r\nall that you did, reflected in one of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou put your candle on the top of the cabinet. You opened, and shut,\r\none drawer after another, until you came to the drawer in which I had\r\nput my Diamond. You looked at the open drawer for a moment. And then\r\nyou put your hand in, and took the Diamond out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know I took the Diamond out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw your hand go into the drawer. And I saw the gleam of the stone\r\nbetween your finger and thumb, when you took your hand out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid my hand approach the drawer again\xe2\x80\x94to close it, for instance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. You had the Diamond in your right hand; and you took the candle\r\nfrom the top of the cabinet with your left hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I look about me again, after that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I leave the room immediately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. You stood quite still, for what seemed a long time. I saw your\r\nface sideways in the glass. You looked like a man thinking, and\r\ndissatisfied with his own thoughts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou roused yourself on a sudden, and you went straight out of the\r\nroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I close the door after me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. You passed out quickly into the passage, and left the door open.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, your light disappeared, and the sound of your steps died away,\r\nand I was left alone in the dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid nothing happen\xe2\x80\x94from that time, to the time when the whole house\r\nknew that the Diamond was lost?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure of that? Might you not have been asleep a part of the\r\ntime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never slept. I never went back to my bed. Nothing happened until\r\nPenelope came in, at the usual time in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI dropped her hand, and rose, and took a turn in the room. Every\r\nquestion that I could put had been answered. Every detail that I could\r\ndesire to know had been placed before me. I had even reverted to the\r\nidea of sleep-walking, and the idea of intoxication; and, again, the\r\nworthlessness of the one theory and the other had been proved\xe2\x80\x94on the\r\nauthority, this time, of the witness who had seen me. What was to be\r\nsaid next? what was to be done next? There rose the horrible fact of\r\nthe Theft\xe2\x80\x94the one visible, tangible object that confronted me, in the\r\nmidst of the impenetrable darkness which enveloped all besides! Not a\r\nglimpse of light to guide me, when I had possessed myself of Rosanna\r\nSpearman\xe2\x80\x99s secret at the Shivering Sand. And not a glimpse of light\r\nnow, when I had appealed to Rachel herself, and had heard the hateful\r\nstory of the night from her own lips.\r\n\r\nShe was the first, this time, to break the silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have asked, and I have answered. You have made\r\nme hope something from all this, because _you_ hoped something from it.\r\nWhat have you to say now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tone in which she spoke warned me that my influence over her was a\r\nlost influence once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were to look at what happened on my birthday night, together,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nwent on; \xe2\x80\x9cand we were then to understand each other. Have we done\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe waited pitilessly for my reply. In answering her I committed a\r\nfatal error\xe2\x80\x94I let the exasperating helplessness of my situation get the\r\nbetter of my self-control. Rashly and uselessly, I reproached her for\r\nthe silence which had kept me until that moment in ignorance of the\r\ntruth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had spoken when you ought to have spoken,\xe2\x80\x9d I began; \xe2\x80\x9cif you had\r\ndone me the common justice to explain yourself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe broke in on me with a cry of fury. The few words I had said seemed\r\nto have lashed her on the instant into a frenzy of rage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain myself!\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cOh! is there another man like this in\r\nthe world? I spare him, when my heart is breaking; I screen him when my\r\nown character is at stake; and _he_\xe2\x80\x94of all human beings, _he_\xe2\x80\x94turns on\r\nme now, and tells me that I ought to have explained myself! After\r\nbelieving in him as I did, after loving him as I did, after thinking of\r\nhim by day, and dreaming of him by night\xe2\x80\x94he wonders I didn\xe2\x80\x99t charge him\r\nwith his disgrace the first time we met: \xe2\x80\x98My heart\xe2\x80\x99s darling, you are a\r\nThief! My hero whom I love and honour, you have crept into my room\r\nunder cover of the night, and stolen my Diamond!\xe2\x80\x99 That is what I ought\r\nto have said. You villain, you mean, mean, mean villain, I would have\r\nlost fifty diamonds, rather than see your face lying to me, as I see it\r\nlying now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI took up my hat. In mercy to _her_\xe2\x80\x94yes! I can honestly say it\xe2\x80\x94in mercy\r\nto _her_, I turned away without a word, and opened the door by which I\r\nhad entered the room.\r\n\r\nShe followed, and snatched the door out of my hand; she closed it, and\r\npointed back to the place that I had left.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cNot yet! It seems that _I_ owe a justification of my\r\nconduct to _you_. You shall stay and hear it. Or you shall stoop to the\r\nlowest infamy of all, and force your way out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt wrung my heart to see her; it wrung my heart to hear her. I answered\r\nby a sign\xe2\x80\x94it was all I could do\xe2\x80\x94that I submitted myself to her will.\r\n\r\nThe crimson flush of anger began to fade out of her face, as I went\r\nback, and took my chair in silence. She waited a little, and steadied\r\nherself. When she went on, but one sign of feeling was discernible in\r\nher. She spoke without looking at me. Her hands were fast clasped in\r\nher lap, and her eyes were fixed on the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought to have done you the common justice to explain myself,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, repeating my own words. \xe2\x80\x9cYou shall see whether I did try to do\r\nyou justice, or not. I told you just now that I never slept, and never\r\nreturned to my bed, after you had left my sitting-room. It\xe2\x80\x99s useless to\r\ntrouble you by dwelling on what I thought\xe2\x80\x94you would not understand my\r\nthoughts\xe2\x80\x94I will only tell you what I did, when time enough had passed\r\nto help me to recover myself. I refrained from alarming the house, and\r\ntelling everybody what had happened\xe2\x80\x94as I ought to have done. In spite\r\nof what I had seen, I was fond enough of you to believe\xe2\x80\x94no matter\r\nwhat!\xe2\x80\x94any impossibility, rather than admit it to my own mind that you\r\nwere deliberately a thief. I thought and thought\xe2\x80\x94and I ended in writing\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never received the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you never received it. Wait a little, and you shall hear why.\r\nMy letter would have told you nothing openly. It would not have ruined\r\nyou for life, if it had fallen into some other person\xe2\x80\x99s hands. It would\r\nonly have said\xe2\x80\x94in a manner which you yourself could not possibly have\r\nmistaken\xe2\x80\x94that I had reason to know you were in debt, and that it was in\r\nmy experience and in my mother\xe2\x80\x99s experience of you, that you were not\r\nvery discreet, or very scrupulous about how you got money when you\r\nwanted it. You would have remembered the visit of the French lawyer,\r\nand you would have known what I referred to. If you had read on with\r\nsome interest after that, you would have come to an offer I had to make\r\nto you\xe2\x80\x94the offer, privately (not a word, mind, to be said openly about\r\nit between us!), of the loan of as large a sum of money as I could\r\nget.\xe2\x80\x94And I would have got it!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, her colour beginning to\r\nrise again, and her eyes looking up at me once more. \xe2\x80\x9cI would have\r\npledged the Diamond myself, if I could have got the money in no other\r\nway! In those words I wrote to you. Wait! I did more than that. I\r\narranged with Penelope to give you the letter when nobody was near. I\r\nplanned to shut myself into my bedroom, and to have the sitting-room\r\nleft open and empty all the morning. And I hoped\xe2\x80\x94with all my heart and\r\nsoul I hoped!\xe2\x80\x94that you would take the opportunity, and put the Diamond\r\nback secretly in the drawer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI attempted to speak. She lifted her hand impatiently, and stopped me.\r\nIn the rapid alternations of her temper, her anger was beginning to\r\nrise again. She got up from her chair, and approached me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what you are going to say,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to\r\nremind me again that you never received my letter. I can tell you why.\r\nI tore it up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what reason?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the best of reasons. I preferred tearing it up to throwing it away\r\nupon such a man as you! What was the first news that reached me in the\r\nmorning? Just as my little plan was complete, what did I hear? I heard\r\nthat you\xe2\x80\x94you!!!\xe2\x80\x94were the foremost person in the house in fetching the\r\npolice. You were the active man; you were the leader; you were working\r\nharder than any of them to recover the jewel! You even carried your\r\naudacity far enough to ask to speak to _me_ about the loss of the\r\nDiamond\xe2\x80\x94the Diamond which you yourself had stolen; the Diamond which\r\nwas all the time in your own hands! After that proof of your horrible\r\nfalseness and cunning, I tore up my letter. But even then\xe2\x80\x94even when I\r\nwas maddened by the searching and questioning of the policeman, whom\r\n_you_ had sent in\xe2\x80\x94even then, there was some infatuation in my mind\r\nwhich wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let me give you up. I said to myself, \xe2\x80\x98He has played his\r\nvile farce before everybody else in the house. Let me try if he can\r\nplay it before me.\xe2\x80\x99 Somebody told me you were on the terrace. I went\r\ndown to the terrace. I forced myself to look at you; I forced myself to\r\nspeak to you. Have you forgotten what I said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI might have answered that I remembered every word of it. But what\r\npurpose, at that moment, would the answer have served?\r\n\r\nHow could I tell her that what she had said had astonished me, had\r\ndistressed me, had suggested to me that she was in a state of dangerous\r\nnervous excitement, had even roused a moment\xe2\x80\x99s doubt in my mind whether\r\nthe loss of the jewel was as much a mystery to her as to the rest of\r\nus\xe2\x80\x94but had never once given me so much as a glimpse at the truth?\r\nWithout the shadow of a proof to produce in vindication of my\r\ninnocence, how could I persuade her that I knew no more than the\r\nveriest stranger could have known of what was really in her thoughts\r\nwhen she spoke to me on the terrace?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may suit your convenience to forget; it suits my convenience to\r\nremember,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on. \xe2\x80\x9cI know what I said\xe2\x80\x94for I considered it with\r\nmyself, before I said it. I gave you one opportunity after another of\r\nowning the truth. I left nothing unsaid that I _could_ say\xe2\x80\x94short of\r\nactually telling you that I knew you had committed the theft. And all\r\nthe return you made, was to look at me with your vile pretence of\r\nastonishment, and your false face of innocence\xe2\x80\x94just as you have looked\r\nat me today; just as you are looking at me now! I left you, that\r\nmorning, knowing you at last for what you were\xe2\x80\x94for what you are\xe2\x80\x94as base\r\na wretch as ever walked the earth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had spoken out at the time, you might have left me, Rachel,\r\nknowing that you had cruelly wronged an innocent man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had spoken out before other people,\xe2\x80\x9d she retorted, with another\r\nburst of indignation, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would have been disgraced for life! If I had\r\nspoken out to no ears but yours, you would have denied it, as you are\r\ndenying it now! Do you think I should have believed you? Would a man\r\nhesitate at a lie, who had done what I saw _you_ do\xe2\x80\x94who had behaved\r\nabout it afterwards, as I saw _you_ behave? I tell you again, I shrank\r\nfrom the horror of hearing you lie, after the horror of seeing you\r\nthieve. You talk as if this was a misunderstanding which a few words\r\nmight have set right! Well! the misunderstanding is at an end. Is the\r\nthing set right? No! the thing is just where it was. I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe\r\nyou _now!_ I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe you found the nightgown, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in\r\nRosanna Spearman\xe2\x80\x99s letter, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a word you have said. You\r\nstole it\xe2\x80\x94I saw you! You affected to help the police\xe2\x80\x94I saw you! You\r\npledged the Diamond to the money-lender in London\xe2\x80\x94I am sure of it! You\r\ncast the suspicion of your disgrace (thanks to my base silence!) on an\r\ninnocent man! You fled to the Continent with your plunder the next\r\nmorning! After all that vileness, there was but one thing more you\r\n_could_ do. You could come here with a last falsehood on your lips\xe2\x80\x94you\r\ncould come here, and tell me that I have wronged you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf I had stayed a moment more, I know not what words might have escaped\r\nme which I should have remembered with vain repentance and regret. I\r\npassed by her, and opened the door for the second time. For the second\r\ntime\xe2\x80\x94with the frantic perversity of a roused woman\xe2\x80\x94she caught me by the\r\narm, and barred my way out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go, Rachel\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will be better for both of us. Let me\r\ngo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hysterical passion swelled in her bosom\xe2\x80\x94her quickened convulsive\r\nbreathing almost beat on my face, as she held me back at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you come here?\xe2\x80\x9d she persisted, desperately. \xe2\x80\x9cI ask you\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94why did you come here? Are you afraid I shall expose you? Now you\r\nare a rich man, now you have got a place in the world, now you may\r\nmarry the best lady in the land\xe2\x80\x94are you afraid I shall say the words\r\nwhich I have never said yet to anybody but you? I can\xe2\x80\x99t say the words!\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t expose you! I am worse, if worse can be, than you are\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d Sobs and tears burst from her. She struggled with them\r\nfiercely; she held me more and more firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tear you out of my\r\nheart,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9ceven now! You may trust in the shameful, shameful\r\nweakness which can only struggle against you in this way!\xe2\x80\x9d She suddenly\r\nlet go of me\xe2\x80\x94she threw up her hands, and wrung them frantically in the\r\nair. \xe2\x80\x9cAny other woman living would shrink from the disgrace of touching\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, God! I despise myself even more heartily than\r\nI despise _him_!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tears were forcing their way into my eyes in spite of me\xe2\x80\x94the horror\r\nof it was to be endured no longer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall know that you have wronged me, yet,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cOr you shall\r\nnever see me again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith those words, I left her. She started up from the chair on which\r\nshe had dropped the moment before: she started up\xe2\x80\x94the noble\r\ncreature!\xe2\x80\x94and followed me across the outer room, with a last merciful\r\nword at parting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFranklin!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI forgive you! Oh, Franklin, Franklin! we shall\r\nnever meet again. Say you forgive _me!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI turned, so as to let my face show her that I was past speaking\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nturned, and waved my hand, and saw her dimly, as in a vision, through\r\nthe tears that had conquered me at last.\r\n\r\nThe next moment, the worst bitterness of it was over. I was out in the\r\ngarden again. I saw her, and heard her, no more.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\nLate that evening, I was surprised at my lodgings by a visit from Mr.\r\nBruff.\r\n\r\nThere was a noticeable change in the lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s manner. It had lost its\r\nusual confidence and spirit. He shook hands with me, for the first time\r\nin his life, in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going back to Hampstead?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, by way of saying something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just left Hampstead,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI know, Mr. Franklin, that\r\nyou have got at the truth at last. But, I tell you plainly, if I could\r\nhave foreseen the price that was to be paid for it, I should have\r\npreferred leaving you in the dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen Rachel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have come here after taking her back to Portland Place; it was\r\nimpossible to let her return in the carriage by herself. I can hardly\r\nhold you responsible\xe2\x80\x94considering that you saw her in my house and by my\r\npermission\xe2\x80\x94for the shock that this unlucky interview has inflicted on\r\nher. All I can do is to provide against a repetition of the mischief.\r\nShe is young\xe2\x80\x94she has a resolute spirit\xe2\x80\x94she will get over this, with\r\ntime and rest to help her. I want to be assured that you will do\r\nnothing to hinder her recovery. May I depend on your making no second\r\nattempt to see her\xe2\x80\x94except with my sanction and approval?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter what she has suffered, and after what I have suffered,\xe2\x80\x9d I said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou may rely on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have your promise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have my promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bruff looked relieved. He put down his hat, and drew his chair\r\nnearer to mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s settled!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, about the future\xe2\x80\x94_your_ future, I\r\nmean. To my mind, the result of the extraordinary turn which the matter\r\nhas now taken is briefly this. In the first place, we are sure that\r\nRachel has told you the whole truth, as plainly as words can tell it.\r\nIn the second place\xe2\x80\x94though we know that there must be some dreadful\r\nmistake somewhere\xe2\x80\x94we can hardly blame her for believing you to be\r\nguilty, on the evidence of her own senses; backed, as that evidence has\r\nbeen, by circumstances which appear, on the face of them, to tell dead\r\nagainst you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere I interposed. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t blame Rachel,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cI only regret that\r\nshe could not prevail on herself to speak more plainly to me at the\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might as well regret that Rachel is not somebody else,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined\r\nMr. Bruff. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd even then, I doubt if a girl of any delicacy, whose\r\nheart had been set on marrying you, could have brought herself to\r\ncharge you to your face with being a thief. Anyhow, it was not in\r\nRachel\xe2\x80\x99s nature to do it. In a very different matter to this matter of\r\nyours\xe2\x80\x94which placed her, however, in a position not altogether unlike\r\nher position towards you\xe2\x80\x94I happen to know that she was influenced by a\r\nsimilar motive to the motive which actuated her conduct in your case.\r\nBesides, as she told me herself, on our way to town this evening, if\r\nshe _had_ spoken plainly, she would no more have believed your denial\r\nthen than she believes it now. What answer can you make to that? There\r\nis no answer to be made to it. Come, come, Mr. Franklin! my view of the\r\ncase has been proved to be all wrong, I admit\xe2\x80\x94but, as things are now,\r\nmy advice may be worth having for all that. I tell you plainly, we\r\nshall be wasting our time, and cudgelling our brains to no purpose, if\r\nwe attempt to try back, and unravel this frightful complication from\r\nthe beginning. Let us close our minds resolutely to all that happened\r\nlast year at Lady Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s country house; and let us look to what we\r\n_can_ discover in the future, instead of to what we can _not_ discover\r\nin the past.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely you forget,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the whole thing is essentially a\r\nmatter of the past\xe2\x80\x94so far as I am concerned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer me this,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Mr. Bruff. \xe2\x80\x9cIs the Moonstone at the bottom\r\nof all the mischief\xe2\x80\x94or is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is\xe2\x80\x94of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good. What do we believe was done with the Moonstone, when it was\r\ntaken to London?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was pledged to Mr. Luker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe know that you are not the person who pledged it. Do we know who\r\ndid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do we believe the Moonstone to be now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeposited in the keeping of Mr. Luker\xe2\x80\x99s bankers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly. Now observe. We are already in the month of June. Towards the\r\nend of the month (I can\xe2\x80\x99t be particular to a day) a year will have\r\nelapsed from the time when we believe the jewel to have been pledged.\r\nThere is a chance\xe2\x80\x94to say the least\xe2\x80\x94that the person who pawned it, may\r\nbe prepared to redeem it when the year\xe2\x80\x99s time has expired. If he\r\nredeems it, Mr. Luker must himself\xe2\x80\x94according to the terms of his own\r\narrangement\xe2\x80\x94take the Diamond out of his banker\xe2\x80\x99s hands. Under these\r\ncircumstances, I propose setting a watch at the bank, as the present\r\nmonth draws to an end, and discovering who the person is to whom Mr.\r\nLuker restores the Moonstone. Do you see it now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI admitted (a little unwillingly) that the idea was a new one, at any\r\nrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. Murthwaite\xe2\x80\x99s idea quite as much as mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bruff. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nmight have never entered my head, but for a conversation we had\r\ntogether some time since. If Mr. Murthwaite is right, the Indians are\r\nlikely to be on the lookout at the bank, towards the end of the month\r\ntoo\xe2\x80\x94and something serious may come of it. What comes of it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmatter to you and me except as it may help us to lay our hands on the\r\nmysterious Somebody who pawned the Diamond. That person, you may rely\r\non it, is responsible (I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know how) for the position in\r\nwhich you stand at this moment; and that person alone can set you right\r\nin Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s estimation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t deny,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the plan you propose meets the difficulty\r\nin a way that is very daring, and very ingenious, and very new. But\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have an objection to make?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. My objection is, that your proposal obliges us to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGranted. As I reckon the time, it requires you to wait about a\r\nfortnight\xe2\x80\x94more or less. Is that so very long?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a life-time, Mr. Bruff, in such a situation as mine. My existence\r\nwill be simply unendurable to me, unless I do something towards\r\nclearing my character at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, I understand that. Have you thought yet of what you can\r\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have thought of consulting Sergeant Cuff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has retired from the police. It\xe2\x80\x99s useless to expect the Sergeant to\r\nhelp you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know where to find him; and I can but try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Bruff, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s consideration. \xe2\x80\x9cThe case has\r\nassumed such an extraordinary aspect since Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s time, that\r\nyou _may_ revive his interest in the inquiry. Try, and let me hear the\r\nresult. In the meanwhile,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cif you make no\r\ndiscoveries between this, and the end of the month, am I free to try,\r\non my side, what can be done by keeping a lookout at the bank?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cunless I relieve you of all necessity for\r\ntrying the experiment in the interval.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Bruff smiled, and took up his hat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell Sergeant Cuff,\xe2\x80\x9d he rejoined, \xe2\x80\x9cthat _I_ say the discovery of the\r\ntruth depends on the discovery of the person who pawned the Diamond.\r\nAnd let me hear what the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s experience says to that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo we parted.\r\n\r\nEarly the next morning, I set forth for the little town of Dorking\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nplace of Sergeant Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s retirement, as indicated to me by Betteredge.\r\n\r\nInquiring at the hotel, I received the necessary directions for finding\r\nthe Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s cottage. It was approached by a quiet bye-road, a little\r\nway out of the town, and it stood snugly in the middle of its own plot\r\nof garden ground, protected by a good brick wall at the back and the\r\nsides, and by a high quickset hedge in front. The gate, ornamented at\r\nthe upper part by smartly-painted trellis-work, was locked. After\r\nringing at the bell, I peered through the trellis-work, and saw the\r\ngreat Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s favourite flower everywhere; blooming in his garden,\r\nclustering over his door, looking in at his windows. Far from the\r\ncrimes and the mysteries of the great city, the illustrious thief-taker\r\nwas placidly living out the last Sybarite years of his life, smothered\r\nin roses!\r\n\r\nA decent elderly woman opened the gate to me, and at once annihilated\r\nall the hopes I had built on securing the assistance of Sergeant Cuff.\r\nHe had started, only the day before, on a journey to Ireland.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he gone there on business?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\nThe woman smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cHe has only one business now, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s roses. Some great man\xe2\x80\x99s gardener in Ireland has found out\r\nsomething new in the growing of roses\xe2\x80\x94and Mr. Cuff\xe2\x80\x99s away to inquire\r\ninto it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know when he will be back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite uncertain, sir. Mr. Cuff said he should come back directly,\r\nor be away some time, just according as he found the new discovery\r\nworth nothing, or worth looking into. If you have any message to leave\r\nfor him, I\xe2\x80\x99ll take care, sir, that he gets it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI gave her my card, having first written on it in pencil: \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nsomething to say about the Moonstone. Let me hear from you as soon as\r\nyou get back.\xe2\x80\x9d That done, there was nothing left but to submit to\r\ncircumstances, and return to London.\r\n\r\nIn the irritable condition of my mind, at the time of which I am now\r\nwriting, the abortive result of my journey to the Sergeant\xe2\x80\x99s cottage\r\nsimply aggravated the restless impulse in me to be doing something. On\r\nthe day of my return from Dorking, I determined that the next morning\r\nshould find me bent on a new effort at forcing my way, through all\r\nobstacles, from the darkness to the light.\r\n\r\nWhat form was my next experiment to take?\r\n\r\nIf the excellent Betteredge had been present while I was considering\r\nthat question, and if he had been let into the secret of my thoughts,\r\nhe would, no doubt, have declared that the German side of me was, on\r\nthis occasion, my uppermost side. To speak seriously, it is perhaps\r\npossible that my German training was in some degree responsible for the\r\nlabyrinth of useless speculations in which I now involved myself. For\r\nthe greater part of the night, I sat smoking, and building up theories,\r\none more profoundly improbable than another. When I did get to sleep,\r\nmy waking fancies pursued me in dreams. I rose the next morning, with\r\nObjective-Subjective and Subjective-Objective inextricably entangled\r\ntogether in my mind; and I began the day which was to witness my next\r\neffort at practical action of some kind, by doubting whether I had any\r\nsort of right (on purely philosophical grounds) to consider any sort of\r\nthing (the Diamond included) as existing at all.\r\n\r\nHow long I might have remained lost in the mist of my own metaphysics,\r\nif I had been left to extricate myself, it is impossible for me to say.\r\nAs the event proved, accident came to my rescue, and happily delivered\r\nme. I happened to wear, that morning, the same coat which I had worn on\r\nthe day of my interview with Rachel. Searching for something else in\r\none of the pockets, I came upon a crumpled piece of paper, and, taking\r\nit out, found Betteredge\xe2\x80\x99s forgotten letter in my hand.\r\n\r\nIt seemed hard on my good old friend to leave him without a reply. I\r\nwent to my writing-table, and read his letter again.\r\n\r\nA letter which has nothing of the slightest importance in it, is not\r\nalways an easy letter to answer. Betteredge\xe2\x80\x99s present effort at\r\ncorresponding with me came within this category. Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s assistant,\r\notherwise Ezra Jennings, had told his master that he had seen me; and\r\nMr. Candy, in his turn, wanted to see me and say something to me, when\r\nI was next in the neighbourhood of Frizinghall. What was to be said in\r\nanswer to that, which would be worth the paper it was written on? I sat\r\nidly drawing likenesses from memory of Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable-looking\r\nassistant, on the sheet of paper which I had vowed to dedicate to\r\nBetteredge\xe2\x80\x94until it suddenly occurred to me that here was the\r\nirrepressible Ezra Jennings getting in my way again! I threw a dozen\r\nportraits, at least, of the man with the piebald hair (the hair in\r\nevery case, remarkably like), into the waste-paper basket\xe2\x80\x94and then and\r\nthere, wrote my answer to Betteredge. It was a perfectly commonplace\r\nletter\xe2\x80\x94but it had one excellent effect on me. The effort of writing a\r\nfew sentences, in plain English, completely cleared my mind of the\r\ncloudy nonsense which had filled it since the previous day.\r\n\r\nDevoting myself once more to the elucidation of the impenetrable puzzle\r\nwhich my own position presented to me, I now tried to meet the\r\ndifficulty by investigating it from a plainly practical point of view.\r\nThe events of the memorable night being still unintelligible to me, I\r\nlooked a little farther back, and searched my memory of the earlier\r\nhours of the birthday for any incident which might prove of some\r\nassistance to me in finding the clue.\r\n\r\nHad anything happened while Rachel and I were finishing the painted\r\ndoor? or, later, when I rode over to Frizinghall? or afterwards, when I\r\nwent back with Godfrey Ablewhite and his sisters? or, later again, when\r\nI put the Moonstone into Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s hands? or, later still, when the\r\ncompany came, and we all assembled round the dinner-table? My memory\r\ndisposed of that string of questions readily enough, until I came to\r\nthe last. Looking back at the social event of the birthday dinner, I\r\nfound myself brought to a standstill at the outset of the inquiry. I\r\nwas not even capable of accurately remembering the number of the guests\r\nwho had sat at the same table with me.\r\n\r\nTo feel myself completely at fault here, and to conclude, thereupon,\r\nthat the incidents of the dinner might especially repay the trouble of\r\ninvestigating them, formed parts of the same mental process, in my\r\ncase. I believe other people, in a similar situation, would have\r\nreasoned as I did. When the pursuit of our own interests causes us to\r\nbecome objects of inquiry to ourselves, we are naturally suspicious of\r\nwhat we don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Once in possession of the names of the persons who\r\nhad been present at the dinner, I resolved\xe2\x80\x94as a means of enriching the\r\ndeficient resources of my own memory\xe2\x80\x94to appeal to the memory of the\r\nrest of the guests; to write down all that they could recollect of the\r\nsocial events of the birthday; and to test the result, thus obtained,\r\nby the light of what had happened afterwards, when the company had left\r\nthe house.\r\n\r\nThis last and newest of my many contemplated experiments in the art of\r\ninquiry\xe2\x80\x94which Betteredge would probably have attributed to the\r\nclear-headed, or French, side of me being uppermost for the moment\xe2\x80\x94may\r\nfairly claim record here, on its own merits. Unlikely as it may seem, I\r\nhad now actually groped my way to the root of the matter at last. All I\r\nwanted was a hint to guide me in the right direction at starting.\r\nBefore another day had passed over my head, that hint was given me by\r\none of the company who had been present at the birthday feast!\r\n\r\nWith the plan of proceeding which I now had in view, it was first\r\nnecessary to possess the complete list of the guests. This I could\r\neasily obtain from Gabriel Betteredge. I determined to go back to\r\nYorkshire on that day, and to begin my contemplated investigation the\r\nnext morning.\r\n\r\nIt was just too late to start by the train which left London before\r\nnoon. There was no alternative but to wait, nearly three hours, for the\r\ndeparture of the next train. Was there anything I could do in London,\r\nwhich might usefully occupy this interval of time?\r\n\r\nMy thoughts went back again obstinately to the birthday dinner.\r\n\r\nThough I had forgotten the numbers, and, in many cases, the names of\r\nthe guests, I remembered readily enough that by far the larger\r\nproportion of them came from Frizinghall, or from its neighbourhood.\r\nBut the larger proportion was not all. Some few of us were not regular\r\nresidents in the country. I myself was one of the few. Mr. Murthwaite\r\nwas another. Godfrey Ablewhite was a third. Mr. Bruff\xe2\x80\x94no: I called to\r\nmind that business had prevented Mr. Bruff from making one of the\r\nparty. Had any ladies been present, whose usual residence was in\r\nLondon? I could only remember Miss Clack as coming within this latter\r\ncategory. However, here were three of the guests, at any rate, whom it\r\nwas clearly advisable for me to see before I left town. I drove off at\r\nonce to Mr. Bruff\xe2\x80\x99s office; not knowing the addresses of the persons of\r\nwhom I was in search, and thinking it probable that he might put me in\r\nthe way of finding them.\r\n\r\nMr. Bruff proved to be too busy to give me more than a minute of his\r\nvaluable time. In that minute, however, he contrived to dispose\xe2\x80\x94in the\r\nmost discouraging manner\xe2\x80\x94of all the questions I had to put to him.\r\n\r\nIn the first place, he considered my newly-discovered method of finding\r\na clue to the mystery as something too purely fanciful to be seriously\r\ndiscussed. In the second, third, and fourth places, Mr. Murthwaite was\r\nnow on his way back to the scene of his past adventures; Miss Clack had\r\nsuffered losses, and had settled, from motives of economy, in France;\r\nMr. Godfrey Ablewhite might, or might not, be discoverable somewhere in\r\nLondon. Suppose I inquired at his club? And suppose I excused Mr.\r\nBruff, if he went back to his business and wished me good morning?\r\n\r\nThe field of inquiry in London, being now so narrowed as only to\r\ninclude the one necessity of discovering Godfrey\xe2\x80\x99s address, I took the\r\nlawyer\xe2\x80\x99s hint, and drove to his club.\r\n\r\nIn the hall, I met with one of the members, who was an old friend of my\r\ncousin\xe2\x80\x99s, and who was also an acquaintance of my own. This gentleman,\r\nafter enlightening me on the subject of Godfrey\xe2\x80\x99s address, told me of\r\ntwo recent events in his life, which were of some importance in\r\nthemselves, and which had not previously reached my ears.\r\n\r\nIt appeared that Godfrey, far from being discouraged by Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwithdrawal from her engagement to him had made matrimonial advances\r\nsoon afterwards to another young lady, reputed to be a great heiress.\r\nHis suit had prospered, and his marriage had been considered as a\r\nsettled and certain thing. But, here again, the engagement had been\r\nsuddenly and unexpectedly broken off\xe2\x80\x94owing, it was said, on this\r\noccasion, to a serious difference of opinion between the bridegroom and\r\nthe lady\xe2\x80\x99s father, on the question of settlements.\r\n\r\nAs some compensation for this second matrimonial disaster, Godfrey had\r\nsoon afterwards found himself the object of fond pecuniary remembrance,\r\non the part of one of his many admirers. A rich old lady\xe2\x80\x94highly\r\nrespected at the Mothers\xe2\x80\x99 Small-Clothes-Conversion-Society, and a great\r\nfriend of Miss Clack\xe2\x80\x99s (to whom she left nothing but a mourning\r\nring)\xe2\x80\x94had bequeathed to the admirable and meritorious Godfrey a legacy\r\nof five thousand pounds. After receiving this handsome addition to his\r\nown modest pecuniary resources, he had been heard to say that he felt\r\nthe necessity of getting a little respite from his charitable labours,\r\nand that his doctor prescribed \xe2\x80\x9ca run on the Continent, as likely to be\r\nproductive of much future benefit to his health.\xe2\x80\x9d If I wanted to see\r\nhim, it would be advisable to lose no time in paying my contemplated\r\nvisit.\r\n\r\nI went, then and there, to pay my visit.\r\n\r\nThe same fatality which had made me just one day too late in calling on\r\nSergeant Cuff, made me again one day too late in calling on Godfrey. He\r\nhad left London, on the previous morning, by the tidal train, for\r\nDover. He was to cross to Ostend; and his servant believed he was going\r\non to Brussels. The time of his return was rather uncertain; but I\r\nmight be sure he would be away at least three months.\r\n\r\nI went back to my lodgings a little depressed in spirits. Three of the\r\nguests at the birthday dinner\xe2\x80\x94and those three all exceptionally\r\nintelligent people\xe2\x80\x94were out of my reach, at the very time when it was\r\nmost important to be able to communicate with them. My last hopes now\r\nrested on Betteredge, and on the friends of the late Lady Verinder whom\r\nI might still find living in the neighbourhood of Rachel\xe2\x80\x99s country\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nOn this occasion, I travelled straight to Frizinghall\xe2\x80\x94the town being\r\nnow the central point in my field of inquiry. I arrived too late in the\r\nevening to be able to communicate with Betteredge. The next morning, I\r\nsent a messenger with a letter, requesting him to join me at the hotel,\r\nat his earliest convenience.\r\n\r\nHaving taken the precaution\xe2\x80\x94partly to save time, partly to accommodate\r\nBetteredge\xe2\x80\x94of sending my messenger in a fly, I had a reasonable\r\nprospect, if no delays occurred, of seeing the old man within less than\r\ntwo hours from the time when I had sent for him. During this interval,\r\nI arranged to employ myself in opening my contemplated inquiry, among\r\nthe guests present at the birthday dinner who were personally known to\r\nme, and who were easily within my reach. These were my relatives, the\r\nAblewhites, and Mr. Candy. The doctor had expressed a special wish to\r\nsee me, and the doctor lived in the next street. So to Mr. Candy I went\r\nfirst.\r\n\r\nAfter what Betteredge had told me, I naturally anticipated finding\r\ntraces in the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s face of the severe illness from which he had\r\nsuffered. But I was utterly unprepared for such a change as I saw in\r\nhim when he entered the room and shook hands with me. His eyes were\r\ndim; his hair had turned completely grey; his face was wizen; his\r\nfigure had shrunk. I looked at the once lively, rattlepated, humorous\r\nlittle doctor\xe2\x80\x94associated in my remembrance with the perpetration of\r\nincorrigible social indiscretions and innumerable boyish jokes\xe2\x80\x94and I\r\nsaw nothing left of his former self, but the old tendency to vulgar\r\nsmartness in his dress. The man was a wreck; but his clothes and his\r\njewellery\xe2\x80\x94in cruel mockery of the change in him\xe2\x80\x94were as gay and as\r\ngaudy as ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have often thought of you, Mr. Blake,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand I am heartily\r\nglad to see you again at last. If there is anything I can do for you,\r\npray command my services, sir\xe2\x80\x94pray command my services!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said those few commonplace words with needless hurry and eagerness,\r\nand with a curiosity to know what had brought me to Yorkshire, which he\r\nwas perfectly\xe2\x80\x94I might say childishly\xe2\x80\x94incapable of concealing from\r\nnotice.\r\n\r\nWith the object that I had in view, I had of course foreseen the\r\nnecessity of entering into some sort of personal explanation, before I\r\ncould hope to interest people, mostly strangers to me, in doing their\r\nbest to assist my inquiry. On the journey to Frizinghall I had arranged\r\nwhat my explanation was to be\xe2\x80\x94and I seized the opportunity now offered\r\nto me of trying the effect of it on Mr. Candy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was in Yorkshire, the other day, and I am in Yorkshire again now, on\r\nrather a romantic errand,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a matter, Mr. Candy, in which\r\nthe late Lady Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s friends all took some interest. You remember\r\nthe mysterious loss of the Indian Diamond, now nearly a year since?\r\nCircumstances have lately happened which lead to the hope that it may\r\nyet be found\xe2\x80\x94and I am interesting myself, as one of the family, in\r\nrecovering it. Among the obstacles in my way, there is the necessity of\r\ncollecting again all the evidence which was discovered at the time, and\r\nmore if possible. There are peculiarities in this case which make it\r\ndesirable to revive my recollection of everything that happened in the\r\nhouse, on the evening of Miss Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s birthday. And I venture to\r\nappeal to her late mother\xe2\x80\x99s friends who were present on that occasion,\r\nto lend me the assistance of their memories\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had got as far as that in rehearsing my explanatory phrases, when I\r\nwas suddenly checked by seeing plainly in Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s face that my\r\nexperiment on him was a total failure.\r\n\r\nThe little doctor sat restlessly picking at the points of his fingers\r\nall the time I was speaking. His dim watery eyes were fixed on my face\r\nwith an expression of vacant and wistful inquiry very painful to see.\r\nWhat he was thinking of, it was impossible to divine. The one thing\r\nclearly visible was that I had failed, after the first two or three\r\nwords, in fixing his attention. The only chance of recalling him to\r\nhimself appeared to lie in changing the subject. I tried a new topic\r\nimmediately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, gaily, \xe2\x80\x9cfor what brings me to Frizinghall! Now, Mr.\r\nCandy, it\xe2\x80\x99s your turn. You sent me a message by Gabriel Betteredge\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left off picking at his fingers, and suddenly brightened up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes! yes! yes!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it! I sent you a\r\nmessage!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Betteredge duly communicated it by letter,\xe2\x80\x9d I went on. \xe2\x80\x9cYou had\r\nsomething to say to me, the next time I was in your neighbourhood.\r\nWell, Mr. Candy, here I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you are!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the doctor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Betteredge was quite right. I\r\nhad something to say to you. That was my message. Betteredge is a\r\nwonderful man. What a memory! At his age, what a memory!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe dropped back into silence, and began picking at his fingers again.\r\nRecollecting what I had heard from Betteredge about the effect of the\r\nfever on his memory, I went on with the conversation, in the hope that\r\nI might help him at starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a long time since we met,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe last saw each other at the\r\nlast birthday dinner my poor aunt was ever to give.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mr. Candy. \xe2\x80\x9cThe birthday dinner!\xe2\x80\x9d He started\r\nimpulsively to his feet, and looked at me. A deep flush suddenly\r\noverspread his faded face, and he abruptly sat down again, as if\r\nconscious of having betrayed a weakness which he would fain have\r\nconcealed. It was plain, pitiably plain, that he was aware of his own\r\ndefect of memory, and that he was bent on hiding it from the\r\nobservation of his friends.\r\n\r\nThus far he had appealed to my compassion only. But the words he had\r\njust said\xe2\x80\x94few as they were\xe2\x80\x94roused my curiosity instantly to the highest\r\npitch. The birthday dinner had already become the one event in the\r\npast, at which I looked back with strangely-mixed feelings of hope and\r\ndistrust. And here was the birthday dinner unmistakably proclaiming\r\nitself as the subject on which Mr. Candy had something important to say\r\nto me!\r\n\r\nI attempted to help him out once more. But, this time, my own interests\r\nwere at the bottom of my compassionate motive, and they hurried me on a\r\nlittle too abruptly, to the end I had in view.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s nearly a year now,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9csince we sat at that pleasant table.\r\nHave you made any memorandum\xe2\x80\x94in your diary, or otherwise\xe2\x80\x94of what you\r\nwanted to say to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Candy understood the suggestion, and showed me that he understood\r\nit, as an insult.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI require no memorandum, Mr. Blake,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, stiffly enough. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nnot such a very old man, yet\xe2\x80\x94and my memory (thank God) is to be\r\nthoroughly depended on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is needless to say that I declined to understand that he was\r\noffended with me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could say the same of _my_ memory,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen _I_ try\r\nto think of matters that are a year old, I seldom find my remembrance\r\nas vivid as I could wish it to be. Take the dinner at Lady Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nfor instance\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Candy brightened up again, the moment the allusion passed my lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! the dinner, the dinner at Lady Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, more\r\neagerly than ever. \xe2\x80\x9cI have got something to say to you about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis eyes looked at me again with the painful expression of inquiry, so\r\nwistful, so vacant, so miserably helpless to see. Trumpery little scandals and quarrels in\r\nthe town, some of them as much as a month old, appeared to recur to his\r\nmemory readily. He chattered on, with something of the smooth gossiping\r\nfluency of former times. But there were moments, even in the full flow\r\nof his talkativeness, when he suddenly hesitated\xe2\x80\x94looked at me for a\r\nmoment with the vacant inquiry once more in his eyes\xe2\x80\x94controlled\r\nhimself\xe2\x80\x94and went on again. I submitted patiently to my martyrdom (it is\r\nsurely nothing less than martyrdom to a man of cosmopolitan sympathies,\r\nto absorb in silent resignation the news of a country town?) until the\r\nclock on the chimney-piece told me that my visit had been prolonged\r\nbeyond half an hour. As we shook hands, Mr. Candy reverted\r\nto the birthday festival of his own accord.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am so glad we have met again,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI had it on my mind\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nreally had it on my mind, Mr. Blake, to speak to you. About the dinner\r\nat Lady Verinder\xe2\x80\x99s, you know? A pleasant dinner\xe2\x80\x94really a pleasant\r\ndinner now, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn repeating the phrase, he seemed to feel hardly as certain of having\r\nprevented me from suspecting his lapse of memory, as he had felt on the\r\nfirst occasion. The wistful look clouded his face again: and, after\r\napparently designing to accompany me to the street door, he suddenly\r\nchanged his mind, rang the bell for the servant, and remained in the\r\ndrawing-room.\r\n\r\nI went slowly down the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s stairs, feeling the disheartening\r\nconviction that he really had something to say which it was vitally\r\nimportant to me to hear, and that he was morally incapable of saying\r\nit. The effort of remembering that he wanted to speak to me was, but\r\ntoo evidently, the only effort that his enfeebled memory was now able\r\nto achieve.\r\n\r\nJust as I reached the bottom of the stairs, and had turned a corner on\r\nmy way to the outer hall, a door opened softly somewhere on the ground\r\nfloor of the house, and a gentle voice said behind me:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid, sir, you find Mr. Candy sadly changed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI turned round, and found myself face to face with Ezra Jennings.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\nThe doctor\xe2\x80\x99s pretty housemaid stood waiting for me, with the street\r\ndoor open in her hand. Pouring brightly into the hall, the morning\r\nlight fell full on the face of Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s assistant when I turned, and\r\nlooked at him.\r\n\r\nIt was impossible to dispute Betteredge\xe2\x80\x99s assertion that the appearance\r\nof Ezra Jennings, speaking from a popular point of view, was against\r\nhim. His gipsy-complexion, his fleshless cheeks, his gaunt facial\r\nbones, his dreamy eyes, his extraordinary parti-coloured hair, the\r\npuzzling contradiction between his face and figure which made him look\r\nold and young both together\xe2\x80\x94were all more or less calculated to produce\r\nan unfavourable impression of him on a stranger\xe2\x80\x99s mind. And yet\xe2\x80\x94feeling\r\nthis as I certainly did\xe2\x80\x94it is not to be denied that Ezra Jennings made\r\nsome inscrutable appeal to my sympathies, which I found it impossible\r\nto resist. While my knowledge of the world warned me to answer the\r\nquestion which he had put, acknowledging that I did indeed find Mr.\r\nCandy sadly changed, and then to proceed on my way out of the house\xe2\x80\x94my\r\ninterest in Ezra Jennings held me rooted to the place, and gave him the\r\nopportunity of speaking to me in private about his employer, for which\r\nhe had been evidently on the watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you walking my way, Mr. Jennings?\xe2\x80\x9d I said, observing that he held\r\nhis hat in his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cI am going to call on my aunt, Mrs. Ablewhite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEzra Jennings replied that he had a patient to see, and that he was\r\nwalking my way.\r\n\r\nWe left the house together. I observed that the pretty servant girl\xe2\x80\x94who\r\nwas all smiles and amiability, when I wished her good morning on my way\r\nout\xe2\x80\x94received a modest little message from Ezra Jennings, relating to\r\nthe time at which he might be expected to return, with pursed-up lips,\r\nand with eyes which ostentatiously looked anywhere rather than look in\r\nhis face. The poor wretch was evidently no favourite in the house. Out\r\nof the house, I had Betteredge\xe2\x80\x99s word for it that he was unpopular\r\neverywhere. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a life!\xe2\x80\x9d I thought to myself, as we descended the\r\ndoctor\xe2\x80\x99s doorsteps.\r\n\r\nHaving already referred to Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s illness on his side, Ezra\r\nJennings now appeared determined to leave it to me to resume the\r\nsubject. His silence said significantly, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s your turn now.\xe2\x80\x9d I, too,\r\nhad my reasons for referring to the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s illness: and I readily\r\naccepted the responsibility of speaking first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudging by the change I see in him,\xe2\x80\x9d I began, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s illness\r\nmust have been far more serious than I had supposed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is almost a miracle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ezra Jennings, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he lived through\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs his memory never any better than I have found it today? He has been\r\ntrying to speak to me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf something which happened before he was taken ill?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\r\nassistant, observing that I hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis memory of events, at that past time, is hopelessly enfeebled,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Ezra Jennings. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is almost to be deplored, poor fellow, that\r\neven the wreck of it remains. While he remembers dimly plans that he\r\nformed\xe2\x80\x94things, here and there, that he had to say or do before his\r\nillness\xe2\x80\x94he is perfectly incapable of recalling what the plans were, or\r\nwhat the thing was that he had to say or do. He is painfully conscious\r\nof his own deficiency, and painfully anxious, as you must have seen, to\r\nhide it from observation. If he could only have recovered in a complete\r\nstate of oblivion as to the past, he would have been a happier man.\r\nPerhaps we should all be happier,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, with a sad smile, \xe2\x80\x9cif we\r\ncould but completely forget!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are some events surely in all men\xe2\x80\x99s lives,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nmemory of which they would be unwilling entirely to lose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, I hope, to be said of most men, Mr. Blake. I am afraid it\r\ncannot truly be said of _all_. Have you any reason to suppose that the\r\nlost remembrance which Mr. Candy tried to recover\xe2\x80\x94while you were\r\nspeaking to him just now\xe2\x80\x94was a remembrance which it was important to\r\n_you_ that he should recall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn saying those words, he had touched, of his own accord, on the very\r\npoint upon which I was anxious to consult him. The interest I felt in\r\nthis strange man had impelled me, in the first instance, to give him\r\nthe opportunity of speaking to me; reserving what I might have to say,\r\non my side, in relation to his employer, until I was first satisfied\r\nthat he was a person in whose delicacy and discretion I could trust.\r\nThe little that he had said, thus far, had been sufficient to convince\r\nme that I was speaking to a gentleman. He had what I may venture to\r\ndescribe as the _unsought self-possession_, which is a sure sign of\r\ngood breeding, not in England only, but everywhere else in the\r\ncivilised world. Whatever the object which he had in view, in putting\r\nthe question that he had just addressed to me, I felt no doubt that I\r\nwas justified\xe2\x80\x94so far\xe2\x80\x94in answering him without reserve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I have a strong interest,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cin tracing the lost\r\nremembrance which Mr. Candy was unable to recall. We had by this time left the last houses in the\r\ntown behind us. Ezra Jennings stopped for a moment, and picked some\r\nwild flowers from the hedge by the roadside. \xe2\x80\x9cHow beautiful they are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, simply, showing his little nosegay to me. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how few people\r\nin England seem to admire them as they deserve!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not always been in England?\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I was born, and partly brought up, in one of our colonies. My\r\nfather was an Englishman; but my mother\xe2\x80\x94We are straying away from our\r\nsubject, Mr. Blake; and it is my fault. The truth is, I have\r\nassociations with these modest little hedgeside flowers\xe2\x80\x94It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmatter; we were speaking of Mr. Candy. He found an urgent message from a\r\npatient, waiting for him; and he most unfortunately went at once to\r\nvisit the sick person, without stopping to change his clothes. I was\r\nmyself professionally detained, that night, by a case at some distance\r\nfrom Frizinghall. They agreed with me that it looked serious; but they both\r\nstrongly dissented from the view I took of the treatment. We differed\r\nentirely in the conclusions which we drew from the patient\xe2\x80\x99s pulse. The\r\ntwo doctors, arguing from the rapidity of the beat, declared that a\r\nlowering treatment was the only treatment to be adopted. On my side, I\r\nadmitted the rapidity of the pulse, but I also pointed to its alarming\r\nfeebleness as indicating an exhausted condition of the system, and as\r\nshowing a plain necessity for the administration of stimulants. The two\r\ndoctors were for keeping him on gruel, lemonade, barley-water, and so\r\non. I was for giving him champagne, or brandy, ammonia, and quinine. A\r\nserious difference of opinion, as you see! A difference between two\r\nphysicians of established local repute, and a stranger who was only an\r\nassistant in the house. For the first few days, I had no choice but to\r\ngive way to my elders and betters; the patient steadily sinking all the\r\ntime. I made a second attempt to appeal to the plain, undeniably plain,\r\nevidence of the pulse. Its rapidity was unchecked, and its feebleness\r\nhad increased. The two doctors took offence at my obstinacy. They said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Jennings, either we manage this case, or you manage it. In my place, you would have seen him sinking, hour by\r\nhour; and you would have risked anything, rather than let the one man\r\non earth who had befriended you, die before your eyes. Don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose\r\nthat I had no sense of the terrible position in which I had placed\r\nmyself! There were moments when I felt all the misery of my\r\nfriendlessness, all the peril of my dreadful responsibility. If I had\r\nbeen a happy man, if I had led a prosperous life, I believe I should\r\nhave sunk under the task I had imposed on myself. But _I_ had no happy\r\ntime to look back at, no past peace of mind to force itself into\r\ncontrast with my present anxiety and suspense\xe2\x80\x94and I held firm to my\r\nresolution through it all. I took an interval in the middle of the day,\r\nwhen my patient\xe2\x80\x99s condition was at its best, for the repose I needed.\r\nFor the rest of the four-and-twenty hours, as long as his life was in\r\ndanger, I never left his bedside. Towards sunset, as usual in such\r\ncases, the delirium incidental to the fever came on. It lasted more or\r\nless through the night; and then intermitted, at that terrible time in\r\nthe early morning\xe2\x80\x94from two o\xe2\x80\x99clock to five\xe2\x80\x94when the vital energies even\r\nof the healthiest of us are at their lowest. It is then that Death\r\ngathers in his human harvest most abundantly. It was then that Death\r\nand I fought our fight over the bed, which should have the man who lay\r\non it. I never hesitated in pursuing the treatment on which I had\r\nstaked everything. When wine failed, I tried brandy. When the other\r\nstimulants lost their influence, I doubled the dose. After an interval\r\nof suspense\xe2\x80\x94the like of which I hope to God I shall never feel\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94there came a day when the rapidity of the pulse slightly, but\r\nappreciably, diminished; and, better still, there came also a change in\r\nthe beat\xe2\x80\x94an unmistakable change to steadiness and strength. _Then_, I\r\nknew that I had saved him; and then I own I broke down. I laid the poor\r\nfellow\xe2\x80\x99s wasted hand back on the bed, and burst out crying. An\r\nhysterical relief, Mr. Blake\xe2\x80\x94nothing more! Physiology says, and says\r\ntruly, that some men are born with female constitutions\xe2\x80\x94and I am one of\r\nthem!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe made that bitterly professional apology for his tears, speaking\r\nquietly and unaffectedly, as he had spoken throughout. His tone and\r\nmanner, from beginning to end, showed him to be especially, almost\r\nmorbidly, anxious not to set himself up as an object of interest to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may well ask, why I have wearied you with all these details?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nwent on. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the only way I can see, Mr. Blake, of properly\r\nintroducing to you what I have to say next. Now you know exactly what\r\nmy position was, at the time of Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s illness, you will the more\r\nreadily understand the sore need I had of lightening the burden on my\r\nmind by giving it, at intervals, some sort of relief. I have had the\r\npresumption to occupy my leisure, for some years past, in writing a\r\nbook, addressed to the members of my profession\xe2\x80\x94a book on the intricate\r\nand delicate subject of the brain and the nervous system. My work will\r\nprobably never be finished; and it will certainly never be published.\r\nIt has none the less been the friend of many lonely hours; and it\r\nhelped me to while away the anxious time\xe2\x80\x94the time of waiting, and\r\nnothing else\xe2\x80\x94at Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s bedside. I won\xe2\x80\x99t trouble you at any length\r\nwith my theory on the subject\xe2\x80\x94I will confine myself to telling you only\r\nwhat it is your present interest to know. It has often occurred to me\r\nin the course of my medical practice, to doubt whether we can\r\njustifiably infer\xe2\x80\x94in cases of delirium\xe2\x80\x94that the loss of the faculty of\r\nspeaking connectedly, implies of necessity the loss of the faculty of\r\nthinking connectedly as well. Poor Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s illness gave me an\r\nopportunity of putting this doubt to the test. I understand the art of\r\nwriting in shorthand; and I was able to take down the patient\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n\xe2\x80\x98wanderings\xe2\x80\x99, exactly as they fell from his lips.\xe2\x80\x94Do you see, Mr.\r\nBlake, what I am coming to at last?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI saw it clearly, and waited with breathless interest to hear more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt odds and ends of time,\xe2\x80\x9d Ezra Jennings went on, \xe2\x80\x9cI reproduced my\r\nshorthand notes, in the ordinary form of writing\xe2\x80\x94leaving large spaces\r\nbetween the broken phrases, and even the single words, as they had\r\nfallen disconnectedly from Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s lips. I then treated the result\r\nthus obtained, on something like the principle which one adopts in\r\nputting together a child\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98puzzle.\xe2\x80\x99 It is all confusion to begin with;\r\nbut it may be all brought into order and shape, if you can only find\r\nthe right way. Acting on this plan, I filled in each blank space on the\r\npaper, with what the words or phrases on either side of it suggested to\r\nme as the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s meaning; altering over and over again, until my\r\nadditions followed naturally on the spoken words which came before\r\nthem, and fitted naturally into the spoken words which came after them.\r\nThe result was, that I not only occupied in this way many vacant and\r\nanxious hours, but that I arrived at something which was (as it seemed\r\nto me) a confirmation of the theory that I held. In plainer words,\r\nafter putting the broken sentences together I found the superior\r\nfaculty of thinking going on, more or less connectedly, in my patient\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind, while the inferior faculty of expression was in a state of almost\r\ncomplete incapacity and confusion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word!\xe2\x80\x9d I interposed eagerly. \xe2\x80\x9cDid my name occur in any of his\r\nwanderings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall hear, Mr. Blake. For nearly the whole of one night, Mr.\r\nCandy\xe2\x80\x99s mind was occupied with _something_ between himself and you. I\r\nhave got the broken words, as they dropped from his lips, on one sheet\r\nof paper. The product (as the\r\narithmeticians would say) is an intelligible statement\xe2\x80\x94first, of\r\nsomething actually done in the past; secondly, of something which Mr.\r\nCandy contemplated doing in the future, if his illness had not got in\r\nthe way, and stopped him. There are\r\ncircumstances in connexion with it that tell against me. I cannot bring\r\nmyself to acknowledge what the accusation is. At\r\nthe outset of my career in this country, the vile slander to which I\r\nhave referred struck me down at once and for ever. I resigned my\r\naspirations in my profession\xe2\x80\x94obscurity was the only hope left for me. I\r\nparted with the woman I loved\xe2\x80\x94how could I condemn her to share my\r\ndisgrace? Evil report, with time and\r\nchance to help it, travels patiently, and travels far. The accusation\r\nfrom which I had fled followed me. I got warning of its approach. I was\r\nable to leave my situation voluntarily, with the testimonials that I\r\nhad earned. They got me another situation in another remote district.\r\nTime passed again; and again the slander that was death to my character\r\nfound me out. On this occasion I had no warning. My employer said, \xe2\x80\x98Mr.\r\nJennings, I have no complaint to make against you; but you must set\r\nyourself right, or leave me.\xe2\x80\x99 I had but one choice\xe2\x80\x94I left him. The one\r\neffectual palliative in my case, is\xe2\x80\x94opium. To that all-potent and\r\nall-merciful drug I am indebted for a respite of many years from my\r\nsentence of death. My nervous system\r\nis shattered; my nights are nights of horror. The end is not far off\r\nnow. Let it come\xe2\x80\x94I have not lived and worked in vain. The little sum is\r\nnearly made up; and I have the means of completing it, if my last\r\nreserves of life fail me sooner than I expect. I hardly know how I have\r\nwandered into telling you this. Without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhesitation I told him the truth, as unreservedly as I have told it in\r\nthese pages.\r\n\r\nHe started to his feet, and looked at me with breathless eagerness as I\r\napproached the leading incident of my story.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is certain that I went into the room,\xe2\x80\x9d I said; \xe2\x80\x9cit is certain that\r\nI took the Diamond. I can only meet those two plain facts by declaring\r\nthat, do what I might, I did it without my own knowledge\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEzra Jennings caught me excitedly by the arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have suggested more to me than you suppose. Have\r\n_you_ ever been accustomed to the use of opium?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never tasted it in my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere your nerves out of order, at this time last year? Were you\r\nunusually restless and irritable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you sleep badly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWretchedly. Many nights I never slept at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas the birthday night an exception? Try, and remember. Did you sleep\r\nwell on that one occasion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do remember! I slept soundly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe dropped my arm as suddenly as he had taken it\xe2\x80\x94and looked at me with\r\nthe air of a man whose mind was relieved of the last doubt that rested\r\non it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a marked day in your life, and in mine,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gravely. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nam absolutely certain, Mr. Blake, of one thing\xe2\x80\x94I have got what Mr.\r\nCandy wanted to say to you this morning, in the notes that I took at my\r\npatient\xe2\x80\x99s bedside. Wait! that is not all. I am firmly persuaded that I\r\ncan prove you to have been unconscious of what you were about, when you\r\nentered the room and took the Diamond. Give me time to think, and time\r\nto question you. I believe the vindication of your innocence is in my\r\nhands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake! What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the excitement of our colloquy, we had walked on a few steps, beyond\r\nthe clump of dwarf trees which had hitherto screened us from view.\r\nBefore Ezra Jennings could answer me, he was hailed from the high road\r\nby a man, in great agitation, who had been evidently on the look-out\r\nfor him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am coming,\xe2\x80\x9d he called back; \xe2\x80\x9cI am coming as fast as I can!\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nturned to me. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is an urgent case waiting for me at the village\r\nyonder; I ought to have been there half an hour since\xe2\x80\x94I must attend to\r\nit at once. Give me two hours from this time, and call at Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94and I will engage to be ready for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow am I to wait!\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed, impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you quiet my mind\r\nby a word of explanation before we part?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is far too serious a matter to be explained in a hurry, Mr.\r\nBlake. I am not wilfully trying your patience\xe2\x80\x94I should only be adding\r\nto your suspense, if I attempted to relieve it as things are now. At\r\nFrizinghall, sir, in two hours\xe2\x80\x99 time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man on the high road hailed him again. He hurried away, and left\r\nme.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\nHow the interval of suspense in which I was now condemned might have\r\naffected other men in my position, I cannot pretend to say. The\r\ninfluence of the two hours\xe2\x80\x99 probation upon _my_ temperament was simply\r\nthis. I felt physically incapable of remaining still in any one place,\r\nand morally incapable of speaking to any one human being, until I had\r\nfirst heard all that Ezra Jennings had to say to me.\r\n\r\nIn this frame of mind, I not only abandoned my contemplated visit to\r\nMrs. Ablewhite\xe2\x80\x94I even shrank from encountering Gabriel Betteredge\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nReturning to Frizinghall, I left a note for Betteredge, telling him\r\nthat I had been unexpectedly called away for a few hours, but that he\r\nmight certainly expect me to return towards three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\nafternoon. I requested him, in the interval, to order his dinner at the\r\nusual hour, and to amuse himself as he pleased. He had, as I well knew,\r\nhosts of friends in Frizinghall; and he would be at no loss how to fill\r\nup his time until I returned to the hotel.\r\n\r\nThis done, I made the best of my way out of the town again, and roamed\r\nthe lonely moorland country which surrounds Frizinghall, until my watch\r\ntold me that it was time, at last, to return to Mr. Candy\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\nI found Ezra Jennings ready and waiting for me.\r\n\r\nHe was sitting alone in a bare little room, which communicated by a\r\nglazed door with a surgery. Hideous coloured diagrams of the ravages of\r\nhideous diseases decorated the barren buff-coloured walls. A bookcase\r\nfilled with dingy medical works, and ornamented at the top with a\r\nskull, in place of the customary bust; a large deal table copiously\r\nsplashed with ink; wooden chairs of the sort that are seen in kitchens\r\nand cottages; a threadbare drugget in the middle of the floor; a sink\r\nof water, with a basin and waste-pipe roughly let into the wall,\r\nhorribly suggestive of its connection with surgical\r\noperations\xe2\x80\x94comprised the entire furniture of the room. The bees were\r\nhumming among a few flowers placed in pots outside the window; the\r\nbirds were singing in the garden, and the faint intermittent jingle of\r\na tuneless piano in some neighbouring house forced itself now and again\r\non the ear. In any other place, these everyday sounds might have spoken\r\npleasantly of the everyday world outside. Here, they came in as\r\nintruders on a silence which nothing but human suffering had the\r\nprivilege to disturb. I looked at the mahogany instrument case, and at\r\nthe huge roll of lint, occupying places of their own on the\r\nbookshelves, and shuddered inwardly as I thought of the sounds,\r\nfamiliar and appropriate to the everyday use of Ezra Jennings\xe2\x80\x99 room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI make no apology, Mr. Blake, for the place in which I am receiving\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the only room in the house, at this hour of the\r\nday, in which we can feel quite sure of being left undisturbed. Here\r\nare my papers ready for you; and here are two books to which we may\r\nhave occasion to refer, before we have done. Bring your chair to the\r\ntable, and we shall be able to consult them together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI drew up to the table; and Ezra Jennings handed me his manuscript\r\nnotes. They consisted of two large folio leaves of paper. One leaf\r\ncontained writing which only covered the surface at intervals. The\r\nother presented writing, in red and black ink, which completely filled\r\nthe page from top to bottom. In the irritated state of my curiosity, at\r\nthat moment, I laid aside the second sheet of paper in despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave some mercy on me!\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me what I am to expect, before I\r\nattempt to read this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly, Mr. Blake!
